loans.name: Faustine

texts.en: Faustine is a married woman and mother to five children. She is the sole owner of a mini-retail shop which deals specifically with essential items most commonly used in the community such as sugar, bread, kerosene, soap, and many others. She initiated this in 1998 from her small savings. Faustine has applied for her first loan of Kenya Shillings 30,000 which she will use  to buy additional stock of commodities not currently stocked. Faustine's dream is to expand into a wholesale store.

loans.use: Buy additional stock of commodities

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary H. is currently in the business of selling fresh vegetables in a market and is requesting a loan to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell.  Mary is 30 years old and married.  Her husband is a teacher. She has 5 school-age children.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen is a married and proud mother of six children. She says they are God’s gift. Hellen is the proprietor of a tailoring and dressmaking shop located at Malanga shopping center in Nambale. She has been in this business for the last 20 years. She specializes in both ladies' and children's clothings since they are selling fast. She has applied for a loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: Improving her clothing business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is forty four years old. She is married and has two children. Elizabeth’s older child recently completed senior high school and is on the way to university.  Her younger child is in senior high school. She is a retailer of building materials such as iron rods, widow frames, nails, paints etc. Elizabeth buys her supplies from wholesalers and retails to her customers. She is handicapped by low working capital since prices of building materials have gone up. She therefore needs the loan to buy more stock and remain in business. She believes this will enable her to make good income from her business to support her family.

loans.use: To purchase building materials in bulk.

loans.name: Milagrosa Group

texts.es:
Aurora Cuarite necesita el préstamo para comprar una máquina de costura ya que ella sabe confeccionar pantalones,  Betty H. necesita comprar lana para tejer buzos, chompas o el pedido que tenga, Marta P. cuenta con una máquina de tejer y necesita comprar lana. Como se describe la mayoría de las integrantes del grupo Milagrosa se dedican a la producción de ropa todas son madres de familia con un promedio de 3 a 4 hijos. 
El nombre del grupo es porque todas ellas viven alrededor de la Iglesia que llama Virgen Milagrosa, de la zona Pedro Domingo.
texts.en:
Aurora Cuarite needs a loan to buy a sewing machine, now that she knows how to make pants. Betty H. needs to buy material to sew sweatshirts, sweaters, or other requests she may receive. Marta P. has her own sewing machine but needs wool.

As described here, the majority of the members of the Miraculous Group are dedicated to the production of clothing. They are all mothers of families averaging 3 to 4 children.

The group name results from the fact that they all live around the church named Miraculous Virgin in the Pedro Domingo Zone.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY SEWING MACHINES AND PRIME MATERIALS FOR SEWING GARMENTS TO SELL

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy sells baby clothes and shoes. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is 26 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a commercial driver.  As a LAPO client, Joy is a recipient of LAPO's commitment to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She needs a loan in the amount of NGN 60,000 to purchase more baby clothes for her shop. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby clothes for her shop

loans.name: Look To We Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Look To We' group. These women are petty business people in the small town of Waterloo, located near Freetown, the capital city. They have been in business for many years now but due to the lack of sufficient working capital, their businesses have not been performing in an encouraging manner. This has therefore led them to SMT/'Shine on Sierra Leone' to apply for a loan of SLL 600,000 each. With this loan at hand, they can expand their businesses both in terms of size and quality.

The group’s leader is Isatu A. K. on the left of the photo. The 41-year-old sells peppers, green leaves (used in cooking), green seeds, okra (used in sauce) and other market food. Isatu A. K. who was born in Makeni city is now residing and doing her business in Waterloo. She has been a businesswoman for more than ten years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy four bags of peppers and twenty dozen green seeds. She sells the seeds to farmers for planting. With the help of this loan, this mother of four, together with her pepper-selling husband, can render great support to their children and in running the home.

loans.use: Buy four bags of peppers and twenty dozen green seeds

loans.name: Liong

texts.en:
Liong J. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local beer.  She is requesting a loan to stock more materials.  Liong is 40 years old and widowed.   She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more materials

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is thirty six years old and married with two children. All her children are still in grade school. She loves fashion very much and as a result, trades in jewels like ear rings, necklaces and other fashionable accessories including beads. The women in her community adorn themselves with the beads. She has been selling jewels for the last six years. She sells her goods house-to-house and also treks to nearby markets. Mary wants to use the loan to buy jewels in bulk so she can trek to other markets. It is her hope to make enough income to support her kids in school.

loans.use: To purchase jewelry in bulk.

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en: Bernard runs a furniture business at Malanga market in Namable. He is a married father of four schoolgoing children. He sells all types of furniture and fittings including beds, chairs and coffee tables. This has been Bernard's only source of income for the last 19 years. He needs a loan to buy stock of materials to make more furniture in readiness for the Christmas season when demand is high.

loans.use: Buy stock of materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Eugenie

texts.en:
Eugenie is 34 years old and is married with four children and two dependents. The children and dependents are aged between 10 and 24. Eugenie and her family live in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Eugenie is a self-employed businesswoman owning a shop selling Irish potatoes. This is her tenth successful year in this business. The hours of her business require that she work from early in morning until late in the evening. 

Eugenie is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase a large quantity of Irish potatoes so that she can satisfy the demands of her customers. With this loan, Eugenie hopes to earn more profit than before.

Eugenie will reinvest a portion of her profit in the business so that she can be financially stable and save some for the future of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more potatoes for sale

loans.name: Pita

texts.en:
Pita S. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local beer. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of charcoal to sell.  Pita is 28 years old and married.  Her husband is a driver.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a charcoal store.

 
 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Eugenie

texts.en:
Eugenie is 46 years old and is married with five children with ages between 5 and 20 years. She has operated her business of selling beverages and cooked food in her restaurant/kiosk for five years. The hours of her business requires that she work from early in the morning until late in the evening (after the last customer leaves, typically).

Eugenie is intent on growing her business. To do this, she is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase some new equipment to be used in her restaurant and to increase the quantity and variety of food and beverages she sells. This, she hopes will result in more customers.

If this strategy is successful, Eugenie, with the additional profit from this business, will be able to continue to build a secure future for her large family.

loans.use: To purchase some new equipment and supplies for her restaurant

loans.name: Jotham

texts.en: Jotham is a 42-year-old married father of five school-going children. He lives with his family in Malanga Nambale. Jotham is a hard-working farmer known for specializing in maize. His farming skills are admired by the government and community members. He gets very high yields from his farm which he is able to sell wholesale to traders. He is preparing his farm for the next planting season and thus requires a loan to help him buy farming needs.

loans.use: Buying farming needs

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ishetu

texts.en:
Ishetu is a 32-year-old, married woman with no children. She trades in garment cloths and polyester, women's slippers and handbags. She normally buys her supplies on credit and pays back after the goods are sold. She is, however, convinced that her business can grow better with increased working capital. She wants to use the loan to purchase items in bulk, such as garment clothes, slippers and handbags to enable her to reduce her costs and raise a good income. 

She hopes to use part of her profit to build a decent shelter for her family in the future.

loans.use: To purchase stock in bulk.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en: Jackson is a 40 year old married father of five children. All of Jackson's children are in school.  Jackson does small scale farming due to limited space and lack of capital. Jackson is unable to lease more farming space and buy farm inputs.  With a loan of Kshs 30,000, he will be able to use half to get farming space and the remainder to buy farm seeds and prepare the ground for planting.

loans.use: Lease more farm space and purchase seeds

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: C2587 Twihaze Group

texts.en:
Donatha is 39 years old and married with four children aged between 2 and 15. She lives in Gasabo district in Kigali province, the capital of Rwanda. Donatha is the group representative of Twihaze group, which consists of five entrepreneurs with various businesses like clothes, small fishes, and bananas.

Donatha owns a small shop which sells different kinds of foodstuff such as sorghum, beans, etc. She has three years of experience in this business, but her monthly profit is too low, so she is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to improve her benefit. With the profit she hopes to earn, she will be able to save money that will allow her to help her husband buy a house for her family.

loans.use: Purchase more beans, sorghum

loans.name: Tom

texts.en:
Tom is married and has two children named Clifford and Joan. He was introduced to KADET through existing clients, is now on his third loan and has had no other loans from other MFIs. 

With the loan, Tom intends to increase his stock of cereals and vegetables. Tom has has a food kiosk for two years.

Tom's business is located in a busy place and has many customers. His main customers are casual laborers who are employed near the client's business.

With the extra profits, the client will start selling cereals wholesale as he hopes to start another food kiosk in another location to maximize profits.

Tom believes that by being hardworking, he will provide for his family and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: Increase stock of cereals and vegetables

loans.name: Ezra Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Felicia is forty-seven years old. She is divorced and has three children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Axim. 

Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. While the fishing industry is the major occupation of the people, Felicia deals in secondhand clothes. She is the leader of a trust bank group called Ezra. The members of the group are mainly traders. The group is requesting a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. They share a desire to provide their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Brown

texts.en: Brown is a 39-year-old entrepreneur. He is married and is blessed with 3 school-going children. He lives in Nambale where he also runs a shop. He buys school uniforms in bulk from Busia and sells them in the local community, his main target being the schools in the area. He started this in 2004. He has applied for a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to enable him obtain stock of school pullovers.

loans.use: Buy stock of pullovers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua is thirty five years old. He is married with four children who are currently in school. He is a graphic designer who prints books, complementary cards, and tributes. He is a photographer in addition to his graphic design business. Joshua says his machines are getting much older and he needs a loan to buy new machines to replace them. Joshua takes orders from corporate businesses and individuals and he believes in efficiency and timely delivery. He believes your support will help his business succeed.

loans.use: To purchase new printing machines.

loans.name: Trust We Group

texts.en:
These are a group of local entrepreneurs in the small town of Waterloo near Freetown. They named their group 'Trust We' and made Mamusu B. (in the middle of the photo) the leader of the group. These entrepreneurs have applied for a loan of SLL 1,500,000 (or SLL 500,000 each) from SMT, a partner of 'Shine on Sierra Leone' in Waterloo. With a loan at their disposal, they can expand their businesses by adding more goods. Consequently, sales and sales-to-profit margins will increase for these entrepreneurs. They will thus be able to better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing and in paying their school fees and other school related expenses.

Mamusu was born in Kambia, in northern Sierra Leone. Mamusu is divorced with two children. One of her children is in Junior Secondary School III and the other is in Primary School V. Since 2000, Mamusu has been selling fried meat, fried chicken, roasted fish and bread. Mamusu wants this loan in order to buy in larger quantity the materials she needs in preparing the meat, fish and chickens she sells – condiments, gallons of oil, charcoal, and so on.

loans.use: To buy in larger quantity the materials she needs in preparing the meat, fish and chickens she sells

loans.name: Abieyuwa

texts.en: Abieyuwa sells dried pepper at retail prices to make a living. She has been in this line of business for a long time. Dried pepper is used as a soup ingredient in Nigeria. The demands for her dried pepper are high and she hopes to meet this demand. She is 42 years old and married with six children. Her husband is a civil servant, and he also supports the home. She says her major challenge in her business is insufficient funds. She is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more dried pepper to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried pepper to sell

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina is 58 years old, married, and the mother of six children. She lives with her family in Malanga Nambale. Regina has been in the cereal business since 1989. She buys cereals in bulk from farmers during harvesting seasons and then sells the cereals when prices improve. This enables her to make good returns. This harvesting season, she plans to buy several bags of maize with a loan of Ksh 25,000 that she has requested.

loans.use: Buy stock of cereals in bulk

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is a 32-year-old married woman. Though she does not have a child of her own, she cares for some of her nieces. She lives with her husband and nieces in a rented apartment in Axim, which is situated along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. In this particular region, the majority of the population is engaged in the fishing business.

To earn a living, Anita is a hair-dresser. She has some apprentices who are training under her. Her shop is conveniently located by the road side in her community. Anita has been in business for seven years, and she is seeking a loan in the amount of $1,075 to buy more working materials to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional materials (e.g.,artificial hair)

loans.name: Edith Namosusoke‘S Group

texts.en:
Edith is a 60-year-old married woman with four children. Her children are between the ages of 28 and 50 years, and some of them go to school. She resides in and owns a four-room house, where she lives with six people. Edith takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water, and generally eats three meals per day.

To earn a living, Edith has a stall in Nsooba, where she sells crafts. She incurs significant transportation costs because she has to travel to purchase bananas and crafts in villages throughout Uganda. She works, seven days per week, in a semi-urban area, which is located in the outskirts of Kampala. On average, she has 50 customers per day, and sells to all kinds of people (i.e., both retail and wholesale customres). Her largest monthly expenses include: costs of feeding her family; school tuition fees for her children; and rental dues for her market stall. Among her major business challenges are the seasonal nature of the business and the rainy season, which makes it difficult for her customers to reach her stall (because she works in an area that can be muddy). She has been in this business for ten years, and she has been with MCDT for six years.

She is currently servicing her nineteenth loan. Edith joined MCDT because it was near her home and because it helped poor women. She is seeking this loan in the amount of $725 to buy more crafts. She wants to see her business grow and to sell solely to wholesale customers.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional crafts

loans.name: Everlyne

texts.en: Everlyne is a 39 year old married woman. Sh is the sole owner of a mini-hotel which deals specifically with food. This is Hellen’s only source of income and she started the business 3 years ago. She requires a loan of Kshs 25,000  to pay rent for her business premise, renovate it to meet her customers preferences, buy more kitchen utensils and restocked the food supplies for the business. According to Everlyne, the business will  pick up during the upcoming Christmas festive season.

loans.use: Pay rent for her business premise and restock food supplies.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is 36 years old. She is married and has two children who are both in school. She lives with her children and her husband in a rented apartment in Axim, which is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Most people in Axim are involved in the fishing business.

Janet has been a seamstress by profession for thirteen years. She has six apprentices who she is in the process of training. In order to expand her seamstress business and to provide a better service to her client base, she is seeking a loan in the amount of $1,075 to purchase different kinds of fabrics and other sewing accessories.

loans.use: To expand and improve her seamstress business by purchasing sewing accessories and different fabrics.

loans.name: Kwadwo

texts.en: Kwadwo is fifty-two years old. He is married with two kids aged four and one. He operates a pharmaceutical shop in his neighborhood and sells various kinds of drugs like blood tonic, pain killers, and malaria drugs. Many local people patronize his pharmacy for first aid drugs and cures when they are sick. He wants to use the loan to increase his supplies of drugs to include others that are frequently requested by his customers. He hopes to raise a good income to take care of his family.

loans.use: To buy pharmaceutical drugs in bulk.

loans.name: Foumale

texts.en: Foumale is a 37-year-old married woman. She has been working as a home-based hairdresser since 2001 to help her husband in raising their 6 children. Today, Foumale ia requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy beauty products and hair appliances to satisfy the needs of the market.

loans.use: To buy beauty products and hair appliances

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy sells groceries, foodstuffs and clothes. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her immediate family members. She is 36 years old and married with four children. Joy is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries, foodstuffs and clothes to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, foodstuffs and clothes to sell

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina is thirty-six years old. She is married and has given birth to three children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Faustina is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew. Faustina also runs a provision store. She has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Balimaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Balimaya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Wobougou, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles à savoir les céréales, les condiments alimentaires et bien d’autres articles divers.
Ces femmes ont intégré l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire et le premier prêt a été bien remboursé. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité d’articles divers, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires de différentes sortes et des céréales. Elles s’approvisionnent sur place et dans les villages environnants elles effectuent leurs ventes sur place et au marché de Dioïla à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 15 000FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Balimaya group are all married women with an average age of 45 and on average, 4 children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families, and live in the village of Wobougou, prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro, and Republic of Mali.

They met each other through ties of neighborhood and kinship. They sell different items such as cereals, condiments and many other various articles.

These women joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to perpetuate their money-making activity. This is their second group loan, and the first one was fully reimbursed.

With this new loan, they wish to buy a large quantity of various items, a large quantity of condiments, and different kind of cereals. They get their goods locally or from neighboring villages. They sell their goods on the spot and at the Dioila market to customers composed of women and men.

They are planning on making an average monthly profit of 15, 000 FCFA per person. The profits are in part reinvested in the business and the other part in the daily family expenses.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is married and a mother of three children. She lives with her family in Likoni Mombasa. Her business is poultry farming. She says the loan of Khs 30,000 will help her  improve her business structure, buy 250 chicks and chicken feed. She says this will increase her clientele and indirectly improve her living standards. Her future dream is to venture into the tailoring materials business.

loans.use: to buy 250 chicks and chicken feed

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nicholas Weru

texts.en:
Nicholas is married to Beatrice and they have three children: Caro, Margaret and Robert who are 28, 28 and 25 years old respectively.

Nicholas was introduced to KADET through existing clients and has no previous credit history. He is in the livestock business and manufactures livestock products. He has been in the livestock business for three years.

Nicholas manufactures livestock feeds and medicines in a government institution and supplies them to farmers across the country. Nicholas business is located within a government institution. He will use the amount from the loan to invest in his manufacturing business and with the extra profits he will invest in machinery as he hopes to own a factory.

Nicholas hopes to improve his lifestyle and that of his family as he believes he is focused and hardworking.

loans.use: The loan will be used to buy raw materials for production of different products for livestock

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkan sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans et 6 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Wobougou, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Ces femmes ont intégré  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé. 
Avec ce  nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaire de différentes sortes à Dioïla et des céréales sur place et dans les villages environnants. Elles revendent sur place et au marché de Dioïla  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de  20.000F CFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont répartis entre l’activité proprement dite et les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkan group are married women who are, on average, 41 years old with 6 children. With their husband and children, they live in large traditional households in the village of Wobougou, Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali. They know each other through neighbourhood and familial relations. These women joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners), with the goal of making their lucrative businesses more durable. They are on their second solidarity (group) loan, and the previous one was repaid properly. With this new loan, they intend to buy a large quantity of food condiments of different types in Dioïla and cereals both on-the-spot and in the neighbouring villages. They sell their goods on-the-spot and at the market in Dioïla to a clientele composed of women and men. They foresee realizing a monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA each. The profit will be shared between the above-mentioned activities and the family expenses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereals and condiments

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is thirty – nine years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both are in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people in her region. Alice is a trader. She trades in food stuffs such as maize, cassava, etc. She buys from nearby communities and treks to sell in nearby towns. She has been in business for nine years and wants a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy food stuffs

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is a married woman and a mother of 4 children, a guardian to 2 orphans and also the breadwinner of her family. She runs a business selling eggs and fish on the veranda of her friends retail shop. She started her business in 2007. 

Mary requires Kshs 30,000 to  restock her fish business and  save part of the loan for future needs. She admits her living standards have improved and that the business is doing well. As a result she is thinking of expanding her current business.

loans.use: Improve her fish business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Young Stars Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Young Stars' group. Members of the 'Young Stars' group are small-scale business people in the small town of Waterloo, very close to Freetown, the capital city. They are business people who want a loan in order to further expand their businesses.

Ibrahim S. T. in the middle of the photo is the group’s leader. Ibrahim was born in Port Loko, in northern Sierra Leone, in 1974. He is married to a businesswoman and the two have three children. Ibrahim’s children are attending primary school – one in class five, another in class three, and the last in class two. For more than ten years now, Ibrahim has been a businessman. He sells cigarettes, mints, chewing gum, Vaseline, toothpaste, cosmetics, bottled water, and so on in a kiosk. He also sells firewood and charcoal. With his share of this loan, Ibrahim is going to buy a half carton of cigarettes and with the remainder of the loan, he will buy piles of firewood. A carton of cigarettes cost SLL 450,000 and a pile of firewood costs SLL 4,000.

loans.use: Buy half carton of cigarettes and piles of firewood

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina is thirty – four years old. She is married and has given birth to one child who is in school. She lives with her husband and son in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people in her region. Faustina is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew. Faustina sells in a stall by the road side. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Josinta

texts.en: Josinta runs a tailoring business where she specializes in women's and children's clothes, which sell fast.Josinta is 34 years old, is married and has one child.She lives with her family in Likoni, Mombasa. She says that her business is doing well. She is able to generate enough income to pay for the household expenses and also pay rent for their house. Her future plan is to keep expanding her business with a loan of Kshs 30,000.

loans.use: Expand her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kolamban Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Kolamban sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Bablena, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Ces femmes ont intégré  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. Elles sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire et le prêt précédent a  été bien remboursé. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité d’habillements, des ustensiles de cuisine, des condiments alimentaires et des articles divers tels que les produits manufacturés etc. 
La plupart des produits sont achetés à Dioïla ou à Bamako et sont revendus dans le village et au marché de Dioïla  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 18.500FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Kolamban group are married women who, in average, are 38 years old and have 4 children. They live with their husbands and children in traditional large families, in the village of Bablena located in the Dioïla Prefecture in the Koulikoro region of Mali. They met because they were neighbors or relatives. These women have signed up with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of prolonging their retail business. They are ready for their second joint loan and the previous one has been fully repaid. With this loan they plan to buy large quantity of clothing, cooking utensils, condiments, food and miscellaneous items such as manufactured goods etc. Most of these products are purchased in Dioïla or in Bamako and are sold back in their home village as well as the market in Dioïla to a clientele of both women and men. They anticipate a monthly profit of 18.500FCFA per person. Profits are partly reinvested in the business and partly used to cover the family daily expenses.

Translated from French by caroline Mrejen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Retail of a variety of products (including clothing)

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is twenty eight years old. She is single and mother of one child. She operates a clothing shop in the community market. She sells women's clothing such as jeans, trousers, skirts and tops, among others. She wants to use the loan to buy more supplies of women's clothes to increase her stock and thereby to make more income for her business.  She wants to finance her child’s education. Florence has sold through “hawking” (door-to-door selling) for over four years. She believes your support would enable her improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase used clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Soutra Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Soutra sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Bablena, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Ces femmes ont intégré  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire  et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé. 
Avec ce  nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, plusieurs paires de volailles, des sacs de tubercules, dans les environs et une grande quantité d’habits sur le marché de Dioïla. 
Les articles sont ensuite revendus sur place dans le village et au marché de Dioïla à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 17.500FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont repartis entre l’activité proprement dite et les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The members of the Soutra group are married women who are, on average, 40 years old with 3 children. With their husband and children, they live in large traditional households in the village of Bablena, Dioïla prefecture, Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali. They know each other through neighbourhood and familial relations. These women joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of making their lucrative businesses more profitable. They are on their second solidarity (group) loan, and the previous loan was repaid properly. With this new loan, they intend to buy several pairs of chickens, bags of tubers from the area, and a large quantity of clothes from the market in Dioïla. These items are then resold on-the-spot in the village and at the market in Dioïla to a clientele composed of women and men. They foresee realizing a monthly profit of 17,500 FCFA per person. The profit will be shared between the above-mentioned business and family expenses.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy poultry, tubers, and clothing

loans.name: Celia

texts.es:
La señora Celia es socia del Banco Comunal “Gran Poder” desde hace 9 años atrás, del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Pun. Ella tiene 28 años de edad, es casada y tiene 4 hijos. Estudió secundaria completa y se dedica a la compra y venta de pan y jugo.
Celia nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles comprò ingredientes para hacer el jugo.
Ella solicitará un crédito  de S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles con el cual podrá comprar azúcar, pan, y frutas.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su casa propia en Ilave y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro.
texts.en:
Celia has been a member of the communal bank, "Great Power" for 9 years, in the district of Ilave, province of El Collao, department of Puno. She is 28 years old, is married, and has 4 kids. She finished seconday school and is dedicated to the buying and selling of bread and juice. Celia told us that with her first loan from the Movement Manuela Ramos, in the amount of 300.00 soles, she bought ingredients to make the juice. She is soliciting 1,500.00 soles with which she will be able to buy sugar, bread, and fruit. Her dream for the future is to have her own house in Ilave and for her children to be professionals. The thing she likes the most about her communal bank is the savings.

Translated from Spanish by Cara Gutterman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sugar, bread, and fruit

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is forty two years old. She is married with three children who are currently in school.  She owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood.  Mercy is a very skillful and talented hair dresser. She does all kinds of hair styles like plaiting, perming and fixing of weavons etc. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products including weavons, pomade, shampoo, activators etc. to avoid running out and providing poor service. Mercy also sells soft drinks along side her business.

loans.use: To purchase hair creams and other beauty products

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne N. is 34 year-old lady, married, and a mother of one child.

Anne offers typing and photocopying services in Likono Mombasa. She initiated this in 2005. She says the business is doing well as the number of clients has increased considerably.

She plans to expand her business by supplementing it with the sale of mobile phone accessories and electrical products which are in high demand. She has applied for 30,000 KES to buy stock of mobile accessories and electrical items.

loans.use: Buy stock of mobile accessories.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Juana Lidia

texts.es:
La señora Juana es socia del Banco Comunal “Lupakas” desde hace 3 años atrás, del distrito de Pilcuyo, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 49 años de edad, es casada y tiene 1 hijo. Estudió secundaria completa y se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado y sogas.
Juana nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital y compró sogas.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 3,000.00 nuevos soles con el cual podrá comprar  hilos, lana y nylon.
Su sueño para el futuro es que su hijo sea profesional y pueda continuar con su negocio.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y la puntualidad que hay con las socias.
texts.en:
Juana has been a member of the “Lupakas” communal bank in the Pilcuyo district, El Collao province, and department of Puno, for the past 3 years. She is 49 years old, married, and has one son. She completed secondary studies and she buys and sells cattle and ropes.

Juana tells us that with her first loan at Movimiento Manuela Ramos, which was for 300 PEN, she was able to increase her capital and purchase ropes.

She is asking for this loan of 3000 PEN so that she will be able to purchase thread, wool, and nylon. Her dream for the future is for her son to become a professional and to be able to continue with her business. What she likes most about the communal bank are the savings and the punctuality among the members.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of thread, wool, and nylon

loans.name: Benso Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benso sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans et 5 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Wobougou, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés.  
Ces femmes ont intégré l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. Elles sont à leur deuxième  prêt  et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé. 
Avec ce  nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires (frais, en conserve, séchés etc.) au marché de Dioïla  et revendent au village et environnants à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25.000FCFA par personne. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the group Benso are married women averaging 41 years of age and 5 children each.  With their husband and children, the women live in large traditional families and reside in the village of Wobougou, prefecture of Dioïla, region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali.  They know one another by ties of community and kinship.  These women joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of making their lucrative businesses sustainable and are now on their second loan.  The preceding one was repaid. With this new loan, the group members intend to buy a large quantity of condiments (fresh, canned, dried, etc.) at the Dioïla market and to resell in town and in the area to customers composed of women and men.  The group members envision realizing a monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA per person.  The profits are partly reinvested in the business and partly for covering day-to-day family expenses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying kitchen condiments

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane runs a a tailoring and dressmaking shop in the neighborhood of Likoni in Momabasa, Kenya. She is a single lady with no children. She makes both ladies' and children's dresses. This is Jane’s first loan application (Kshs 30,000) and she plans to use it to expand her stock of dressmaking materials and keep part of it as savings for emergency use. She says the business is doing well; with her profits, she has also managed to start a business dealing in plastics.

loans.use: Buy stock of materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is married with three children. He is 40 years old. His children are still dependent on him, and they are excelling in school. He sells crates of drinks at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to be a major drink distributor in the future. He has been in this business for a long time. He needs a loan of NGN 90,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La señora Juana es socia del Banco Comunal “Gregoria Apaza” desde hace 5 años atrás, del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 56 años de edad, es casada y tiene 12 hijos de los cuales 4 viven con ella. Estudió primaria completa y se dedica a la compra y venta de animales menores.
Juana nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles con los que comprarà animales como: ovejas y gallinas.
Su sueño para el futuro es vivir tranquila y mejorar su alimentación.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y las reuniones con las socias.
texts.en:
Juana has been a member of the communal bank, "Gregoria Apaza" for five years in the district of Ilave, province of El Collao, department of Puno. She is 56 years old, married, and has 12 kids, 4 of whom live with her. She completed her primary studies and is dedicated to the buying and selling of young animals. Juana told us that with her first loan from the Movement Manuela Ramos, in the amount of 300.00 soles, that she was able to increase her capital. She is soliciting a loan of 500.00 soles with which she will buy animals, such as sheep and hens. Her dream for the future is to live peacefully and improve her diet. The things she likes best about her communal bank are the savings and the member meetings.

Translated from Spanish by Cara Gutterman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sheep and hens

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent avec leur mari et enfants dans des familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le quartier Fana coura, ville de Fana, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce  nouveau prêt elles comptent acheter, des trousseaux de tasses, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires de différentes sortes et des habillements à Bamako (capitale du Mali). Les produits sont achetés en gros et sont revendus en détail, au  comptant et souvent à crédit au marché, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de  40.000FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi group are married women with an average age of 26 and on average, 2 children. They live with their husband and children in large traditional families and live in the neighborhood of Fana Coura, town of Fana, sub-prefecture of Fana, region of KOULIKORO, Republic of Mali.

They met one another through neighborhood ties and kinship.

These women work with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwasa in order to perpetuate their money-making activity.

This is their sixth group loan and all the previous loans have been fully reimbursed.

With this new loan they are planning on buying sets of bowls, a large quantity of different kinds of condiments and clothing in Bamako (the capital of Mali). The products are bought wholesale and sold retail, in cash and often on credit to customers made up of women and men.

They each are planning to make an average monthly profit of 40, 000 FCFA. The profits are reinvested in part in the business and the other part in the daily family’s expenses.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bowls, clothing, and condiments

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
La señora Victoria es parte del Banco Comunal “Gregoria Apaza” desD. hace 1 año atrás, del distrito D. Ilave, provincia D. El Collao, departamento D. Puno Ella tiene 50 años D. edad, es casada y tiene 8 hijos D. los cuales 4 viven con ella. Estudió primaria completa y se dedica a la compra y venta D. animales menores.
Victoria nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue D. S/. 500.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito D. S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles con los que podrà comprar cuyes y gallinas para D. esa manera aumentar su negocio.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su casa propia en Ilave. 
Lo que más le gusta D. su Banco Comunal es el ahorro.
texts.en:
Sra. Victoria has been a member of the Gregoria Apaza Communal Bank for a year. She lives in the District of Ilave, Province of El Collao, Department of Puno. Victoria is 50 years old, married, and has 8 children of whom 4 still live with her. She completed her elementary school education and trades small animals for a living.

Victoria tells us that she requested her first loan from Manuela Ramos in the amount of 500 soles so that she could increase her capital. She is now requesting another loan for 1500 soles in order to buy guinea pigs and chickens so that she can expand her business.

Victoria’s dream for the future is have her own house in Ilave. What she enjoys most about her Communal Bank are the savings.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase guinea pigs & chickens

loans.name: G.s. Divino Niño Group

texts.es:
La señora Maria Esperanza Méndez vende ropa la cual ella elabora ya que es costurera, desde hace 9 años, tiene 57 años de edad y junto a su esposo se han esforzado para sacar adelante la familia ya que es una de sus prioridades es que su hijo logre salir adelante, solicita un financiamiento para la compra de materia prima del negocio, ella vende su producto en Managua.
La señora Maria Del Carmen Méndez Martínez posee un negocio que es una pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación desde hace 5 años, es madre de tres hijos dos de los cuales dos  asisten al colegio, ya que el tercero es un niño de tres años, La señora realiza sus compras a camiones repartidores y en el mercado oriental, solicita un financiamiento para invertirlo en la compra de mercadería para el negocio.
texts.en:
Maria Esperanza Méndez has been selling clothes that she makes for nine years. She is a seamstress. She is 57. Together she and her husband have put forth a lot of effort to get the family ahead. One of their priorities is that their son gets ahead. She is asking for a loan to buy raw material for her business. She sells her product in Managua. María del Carmen Méndez Martínez has a mini market, which has been in her house for five years. She has three children. Two go to school, and the third one is three years old. She makes her purchases from delivery trucks and in the eastern market. She is asking for a loan to buy merchandise for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en: Matilda is forty two years old. She is married with three children who are currently in school. She owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood.  Matilda is a very professional and stylish hair dresser. She creates all types of hair styles; like plaiting, perming and applying weave-ons etc. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness in her service, therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weave-ons, pomade, shampoo, activators, etc. in order to improve her service delivery.

loans.use: To purchase assorted hair salon products.

loans.name: Laïdou Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Laïdou sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 27 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le quartier Fana coura, ville de Fana, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire et tous les deux prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter,  500Kg de riz à Niono, 50 casiers de Boisson (sucreries Bramali), 10 pièces de bazin et une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires à Bamako. Les produits sont revendus au marché de Fana à une clientèle  diverse et variée.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 35 000FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Laïdou group are married women with an average age of 27 and on average, 3 children. They live with their husband and children in large traditional families and live in the neighborhood of Fana Coura, town of Fana, sub-prefecture of Fana, region of KOULIKORO, Republic of Mali.

They met one another through neighborhood ties and kinship.

These women work with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwasa in order to perpetuate their money-making activity.

This is their third group loan and the two previous loans have been fully reimbursed.

With this new loan they are planning on buying 500Kg of rice in Niono, 50 cases of beverage (Sucreries Bramali), 10 bolts of damask cloth and a large quantity of condiments in Bamako. The products are sold at the Fana market to diverse and various customers.

They each are planning to make an average monthly profit of 35, 000 FCFA. The profits are reinvested in part in the business and the other part in the daily family’s expenses.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers.

loans.name: Naty Gregoria

texts.es:
La señora Naty es socia del Banco Comunal “Lupakas” desD. hace 3 años atrás, del distrito D. Pilcuyo, provincia D. El Collao, departamento D. Puno. Ella tiene 50 años D. edad, es casada y tiene 6 hijos,  D. los cuales 4 viven con ella. Estudió Primaria completa. Cuenta con una tienda D. abarrotes y paralelamente se dedica a la compra y venta D. animales y venta D. sogas.
Naty nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital y comprar sogas en fardo.
Ella solicitará un crédito D. S/. 2,500.00 nuevos soles, con el cual podrá comprar una vaca.
Su sueño para el futuro es comprar un tractor y tener su capital propio.
Lo que más le gusta D. su Banco Comunal son las reuniones y la puntualidad que existe.
texts.en:
Naty has been a member of the “Lupakas” communal bank for the past 3 years. It is in the Pilcuyo district, in the El Collao province, in the department of Puno. She is 50 years old, married, and has 6 children, 4 of which live with her. She completed primary school. She has a grocery store, buys and sells animals, and sells ropes.

Naty tells us that with her first loan at Movimiento Manuela Ramos, which was for 300 PEN, she was able to increase her capital and purchase ropes in bundles.

She is asking for a loan of 2500 PEN, with which she will be able to purchase a cow. Her dream is to purchase a tractor and to have her own capital. What she likes most about her communal bank are the meetings and the punctuality that exists.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Juan Bautista

texts.en: For forty years Juan has made saddles and accessories for horses. He learned the trade from his father when he was fourteen years old. Juan and his wife have three children ages 7, 10 and 15.  They are all in school. Juan has a long credit history with Fundación León 2000.  This is his ninth loan. All of his loans have gone towards improving his workshop and tools. He dreams that his children will be able to grow up and have professional careers. Juan reports that at the moment the family is dealing with the illness of his eldest daughter.

loans.use: improve workshop and purchase tools

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Mama Esther, as she is called by her numerous customers, is a 48-year-old local restaurant operator. She is married and blessed with two children. She operates a local restaurant at which she prepares and sells local foods like "fufu" and "banku." Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain, and is eaten with all kinds of soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and is eaten with hot pepper or soup. Esther says that the prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditures. She wants to use the loan to buy more ingredients, like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantains, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. She believes your support would enable her to grow the business.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Nieta Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Nieta sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le quartier Fana coura, ville de Fana, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter,  des merceries, des tissus pour en faire des draps, 20 cartons de savon Koulikoro et du riz pour la restauration. Les produits de merceries et tissus sont achetés à Bamako et les autres articles auprès des grossistes de Fana ou des forains. Tous les produits sont revendus au marché   en détail, au comptant ou à crédit  une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes résidant sur place ou venant des grandes viles (forains routiers etc). 
Elles comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 35 000FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the group Nieta are married women averaging 37 years of age and 3 children each.  With their husband and children, the women live in large traditional families and reside in the Fana Coura district, city of Fana, sub-prefecture of Fana, Region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali.  They know one another by ties of community and kinship.  These group members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of ensuring the continuation of their lucrative businesses and are now on their sixth solidarity loan.  All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.  With this loan, the group members intend to buy sewing supplies and fabrics to make bed sheets out of them; 20 boxes of Koulikoro soap; and some rice for food catering.  The sewing supplies and fabrics are purchases in Bamako. And the other goods are from wholesalers in Fana or from fair vendors.  All the goods are sold retail at the marketplace, cash or credit accepted, from women and men residing locally or from large cities (street vendors, etc.) The group members each plan on realizing an average profit of 35,000 francs CFA per month.  The profits are partly reinvested into the business and partly for day-to-day family expenses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth, soap, and grains

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: 30-year-old Nicholas has been working as a motorbike taxi driver for the past three years in Kitengela, Kenya. He describes himself as outgoing and focused. He is married and has one child in school. He needs the loan in order to repair his motorbike.

loans.use: Motorbike Repair

loans.name: Carmen Dora

texts.es:
La señora CARMEN DORA S. V. D. C. tiene 56 años, vive en el distrito D. EL PORVENIR, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal ESPERANZA DEL MAÑANA. La socia presenta estudios hasta 6to D. primaria , refiere que es D. la sierra y que en su época los padres no se preocupaban por brindarles educación a sus hijos. Carmen es V.  y tiene 5 hijos todos mayores e independientes. 
Ella se dedica a atender la bodega que tiene en su casa y con su primer crédito D. 300.00 nuevos soles comprò productos alimenticios como: arroz, azúcar, leche, galletas, golosinas, gaseosas, aceite, fideos, menestras, etc.  para surtir su tienda.
Actualmente necesita un crédito D. 1,700.00 nuevos soles con los que comprarà productos alimenticios para su bodega como: arroz, golosinas, leche, jugos, fideos, menestras, etc. y a la vez comprarà cerveza para abastecer su tienda por fiestas D. fin D. año.
Carmen sueña con aperturar una fuente D. soda en su domicilio el próximo año para lo cual està ahorrando y trabajando arduamente.
texts.en:
Mrs. Carmen, widow of C., is 56 years old, lives in the Porvenir District, in the Trujillo Province, in the department of La Libertad, Peru. She belongs to the “Hope for Tomorrow” Community Bank. She has a sixth graD. education because she is from the mountains. In her parent’s time it was not important to educate your children. Carmen is a widow with five children. They are all grown and independent. Carmen has a small grocery store in her house. With her first loan of 300.00 soles she bought food products such as rice, sugar, milk, cookies, hard candy, soft drinks, oil, noodles, soups, etc. She purchased these supplies in order to proviD. a greater variety of products to her customers. Now she needs a loan of 1,700.00 new soles with which she will buy food products for her store such as rice, hard candy, juices, noodles, soups, etc. Also she will buy beer for her store for New Year’s celebrations. Carmen’s dream is to open a soda fountain in her house next year. In order to reach this goal she is saving and working hard.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy rice, hard candy, milk, juice, noodles, soups etc. and also beer.

loans.name: Eyra De La Soledad

texts.en:
Eyra is 58 years old and has two grown children. Her business is raising pigs and hens for resale. She chose to start this business about seven years ago when she and her husband needed to find a way to increase their household income in order to support the careers of their children. S

he is an excellent client of Fundación Leon 2000 and will use this loan to purchase pigs and hens and feed for both. Eyra dreams of having her own farm and of being self-sufficient. She reports that for a small family they don’t have any problems.

loans.use: Animals and feed

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
La señora Elvira es socia del Banco Comunal “Gran Poder” desde hace 10 años atrás, del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 44 años de edad, es casada y tiene 4 hijos de los cuales 2 viven con ella. Elvira no estudió y se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado.
La socia nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles con el que podrá comprar ovejas y gallinas.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su tienda en Ilave.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro.
texts.en:
Elvira has been a member of the "Gran Poder" communal bank for ten years, in Llave District, El Collao Province, Puno Department. She is 44 years old, married, and has four children, two who live with her. Elvira did not attend school, and she buys and sells livestock. Elvira tells us that with her first loan from Movimiento Manuela Ramos, which was S/. 300 nuevos soles, she was able to increase her capital. She is requesting a loan of S/. 500 nuevos soles, with which she will be able to buy sheep and hens. Her dream for the future is to have a store in Llave. What she most likes about her communal bank are the savings.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel McRoberts, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sheep and hens

loans.name: Sussy

texts.es:
La señora Sussy es socia del Banco Comunal “Gran Poder” desde hace 2 años atrás, del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 26 años de edad, es casada y tiene 1 hijo. Estudió superior completa y se dedica a la venta de alimentos balanceados.
Sussy nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 700.00 nuevos soles con el que podrá comprar alimentos balanceados.
Su sueño para el futuro es ser empresaria.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es la puntualidad de las socias en las reuniones.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sussy is a partner in the Community Bank of “Gran Poder” for the past two years. She is from the district of Ilave, province of El Collao in the area of Puno. She is 26 years old, is married and has one child. She finished her high school studies and is dedicated to the sale of grains. Sussy tells us that her first loan from Manuela Ramos Movment was for S/500 Peruvian nuevos soles which allowed her to increase her capital. She is requesting a loan of S/700 Peruvian nuevos soles with which she will be able to buy grains. Her dream for the future is to be an entrepreneur. What she likes most about the Community Bank is the punctuality of the partners and the meetings.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Kellogg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase feed grains

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.es:
La señora Concepción es socia del Banco Comunal “Gran Poder” desde hace 2 años atrás, del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 35 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 4 hijos. Estudió secundaria completa y tiene su tienda de ferretería.
Concepción nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital y comprar candados, cuchillos, clavos, etc.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 2,500.00 nuevos soles con el cual podrá comprar fierro, alambrón, alambres, clavos, etc.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su tienda propia de ferretería y así poder vivir tranquila.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y la puntualidad de las socias en las reuniones.
texts.en:
Concepción has been s a member of the communal bank, "Great Power" for 2 years, in the district of Ilave, province of El Collao, department of Puno. She is 35 years old, is a single mother and has 4 children. She completed her secondary studies and she has a hardware store. Concepcion told us that with her first loan from the Movement Manuela Ramos, which was for 500.00 soles, she was able to increase her capital and buy padlocks, knives, nails, etc. She is asking for a credit of 2,500.00 soles with which she will be able to buy iron, wires, nails, etc. Her dream for the future is to have her own hardware store so that she can live peacefully. The things she likes the most about the communal bank are the savings and the puntuality of the members at the meetings.

Translated from Spanish by Cara Gutterman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of iron, wire, construction wire, nails, etc

loans.name: Agnes M.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at a primary school in Makeni. The school is divided into a Lower Primary School (classes one to three) and an Upper Primary School (classes four to six). The school was founded in 1974; it has a total of about 770 pupils with a staff of twenty-four teachers. Since its inception in 1974, the school has produced many of the professionals in town and in the country at large.

This school is seeking its second loan from SMT/Kiva Lenders. With their previous loan, staff of this institution were able to meet their most immediate financial challenges, like paying school fees for their children, buying a piece of land, tables and other furniture, and so on. Having completed repaid their loan, a set of ten new teachers have join the group to seek a new loan. With this loan, these teachers can again meet their immediate needs and with their monthly salaries, the school’s bursar will repay SMT/Kiva on their behalf.

Agnes M. L. (third from left) is the head teacher at the Lower Primary school and head of this loan team. L. is fifty-eight years of age. She was born in Bo, Sierra Leone's second capital city. L. is a widow with seven children, five of whom are already grown-ups and two still in school. She is seeking a loan from Kiva Lenders for the second time to enable her to pay school fees for her children. (Beneath are a group of teachers not present for the group snapshot.)

loans.use: Pay school fees and other school-related charges for her children

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
La señora Yolanda es socia del Banco Comunal “Gran Poder” desde hace 3 años atrás, del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 28 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene 3 hijos. Estudió primaria completa y se dedica a la venta de jugos.
Yolanda nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles con el que podrá comprar azúcar, plátanos, papaya, betarraga, alfalfa, etc.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su casa propia en Ilave.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro.
texts.en:
Yolanda, 28, has been a member of the "Gran Poder" communal bank in Ilave district, El Collao province, Puno department for the last 3 years. She lives with her life partner and their three children. She finished elementary school and she sells home-made fruit and vegetable juices. Yolanda tells us that with her first, 300 new sol, loan from the Manuela Ramos Movement she was able to increase her working capital. She will now request a 500 new sol loan with which to buy sugar, bananas, papayas, beets, alfalfa, etc. Her dream for the future is to own her own house in Ilave. What she likes most about her communal bank is the savings.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, banana, papaya, beets, alfalfa.

loans.name: Irma

texts.es:
La señora Irma es socia del Banco Comunal “Gregoria Apaza” desde hace 4 años atrás, del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 41 años de edad, es casada y tiene 4 hijos. Estudió secundaria completa y se dedica a la compra y venta de animales menores.
Irma nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles con el que podrá comprar ovejas y gallinas.
Su sueño para el futuro es que sus hijos sean profesionales.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y las reuniones con las socias.
texts.en:
Irma, 41, has been a member of the "Gregoria Apaza" communal bank in Ilave district, El Collao province, Puno department, for 4 years now. She is married and has 4 children. She completed secondary school and she raises small farm animals. She tells us that she used her first Manuela Ramos Movement loan of 300 new soles to increase her working capital. She will now request 500 new soles to buy sheep and chickens. Her dream for the future is that her children become professionals. What she likes the most about her communal bank is the savings and the get-togethers with her fellow members.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheep and chickens.

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en: Olivia is a 35-year-old wife and mother of four children who are currently in school. She is a serious-minded business woman who works hard to support her husband and provide for her family. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, creams for body and hair, skimmed powdered milk, and the like. She deems the loan as an opportunity to expand her business and wants to use it to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams, etc., to increase her stock. She believes your support would enable her grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk

loans.name: Alicia Rosa

texts.es:
La señora Alicia es socia del Banco Comunal “Gregoria Apaza” desde hace 1 año atrás, del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 21 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos. Estudió secundaria completa y se dedica a la compra y venta de animales.
Alicia nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles con el que podrá comprar dos ovejas y gallinas.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su casa propia en Ilave. 
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro.
texts.en:
Mrs. Alicia has been a member of the “Gregoria Apaza” Community Bank for the past year. She is from the Llave district, from the province of El Collao, in the department of Puno. She is 21 years old, lives with a partner and has two children. She has finished secondary school. She buys and sells animals. With Alicia’s first loan from the “Manuela Ramos” Movement, which was for 500.00 new soles, she was able to increase her working capital. She is asking for a loan of 500.00 new soles that she will use to buy sheep and chickens. Her dream for the future is to have her own house in Llave. What she likes the most about the Community Bank is their savings.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy sheep and chickens.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.es:
La señora Juliana es socia del Banco Comunal “Gregoria Apaza” desD. hace 5 años atrás, del distrito D. Ilave, provincia D. El Collao, departamento D. Puno. Ella tiene 50 años D. edad, es viuda y tiene 4 hijos D. los cuales uno vive con ella. Estudió primaria incompleta y se dedica a la compra y venta D. animales menores.
Juliana nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles  pudo comprar gallinas y ovejas.
Ella solicitará un crédito D. S/. 500.00 nuevos soles con el que podrà comprar una oveja cara negra.
Su sueño para el futuro es mejorar su alimentación y vivir feliz y tranquila.
Lo que más le gusta D. su Banco Comunal es el ahorro.
texts.en:
Juliana has been a member of the "Gregoria Apaza" communal bank in Ilave district, El Collao province, Puno department, for 5 years now. She is 50 years old, a widow, and has 4 children, one of whom still lives with her. She didn't finish elementary school and she raises small farm animals. Juliana tells us that she used her first, 300 new sol, loan from Manuela Ramos Movement to buy chickens and sheep. She now is requesting 500 new soles with which to buy a black face sheep. Her dream for the future is to improve her diet and to live a happy and peaceful life. What she likes best about her communal bank is the savings.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a black face sheep.

loans.name: Sabina

texts.es:
La señora Sabina es socia del Banco Comunal “Gregoria Apaza” desde hace 4 años atrás, del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 67 años de edad, es casada y tiene 4 hijos quienes se encuentran trabajando con ella. Sabina no estudió y se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado.
Ella nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar sus animales como: cuy y gallinas.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles con el que podrá comprar ovejas.
Su sueño para el futuro es vivir tranquila y feliz. 
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sabina is a partner in the Community Bank of “Gregoira Apaza” for the past four years. She lives in the district of Llave, provence of El Collao area of Puno. She is 67 years old, married with four children who work with her. Sabina has no schooling. She makes a living buying and selling livestock. She tells us about her first loan with the Manuela Ramos Movement which was for S/300 Peruvian nuevos soles which allowed her to increase the animals she has such as guinea pigs and hens. She has requested a loan of S/500 Peruvian nuevos soles with which she will be able to buy sheep. Her dream for the future is to live happy and peacefully. What she likes most about the Community Bank are the savings.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Kellogg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheep

loans.name: Esther
