She prepares the orders as sets and then sells them to her customers who need cloth to either decorate their houses or turn into furniture to sell. She repays her supplier when she has sold all the cloth.

Chiv C. is married with three kids: two are married and one is single and attending school. Her husband works as a military policeman. Chiv C. needs a loan to order more cloth to resell to raise more profit.

loans.use: To order additional cloth

loans.name: Lilia's Group

texts.ru:
Хафизова Лилия – лидер данной группы. Ей сорок два года. Лилия вместе со своей семьёй живёт в г. Карабалта. Это провинциальный город. Из–за безработицы многие жители города уехали в столицу, г. Бишкек или за границу на заработки.  В этих условиях, Лилия и её муж, смогли обеспечить себя работой. Они занялись сельским хозяйством. Ведь, местный климат и ландшафт довольно благоприятны для разведения скота и занятия земледелием. Некоторую живность Лилия получила в наследство, и уже на протяжении двадцати лет животноводство явилось их основным источником пропитания. За счёт имения собственного скота, Лилия смогла дать своим детям образование. Старшему сыну девятнадцать лет. Он работает в пельменном цехе. Младшему сыну семнадцать лет. Он пока находится дома и не работает. Оба сына Лилии активно принимают участие в ухаживании за скотом. Поэтому Лилия не испытывает никаких трудностей в своём деле. Лилия обратилась за кредитом, чтобы закупить ГСМ для обработки пахотной земли весной. Они хотят закупить ГСМ сейчас, так как весной они будут значительно дороже. 

Султанову Камзе пятьдесят два года. Жена Камзы работает учительницей в школе. Сам Камза занимается излюбленным занятием – животноводством. Он также продаёт молоко и подрабатывает обрабатывая участки земли. Камза вместе с женой растят троих детей. Старшей дочери двадцать лет. Камза отправил её на учёбу в медицинское училище. Камза надеется получить кредит и вложить средства в покупку ГСМ для переработки земли. 

Ниязовой Дилдепурус пятьдесят один год. У неё трое детей. Дети уже вполне самостоятельные. Старшая дочь замужем, живёт отдельно. Средняя дочь работает в Бишкеке, а младший сын учится в ВУЗе. Муж Дилдепурус работает электриком. Дилдепурус, пять лет, назад открыла своё дело. Она арендовала помещение на рынке и начала предоставлять услуги швеи. Она делает реставрацию и берёт заказы на индивидуальный пошив.  Дилдепурус обратилась за кредитом с целью купить ГСМ для пахоты земли. 

Абдылдаевой Моркан сорок восемь лет. У Моркан трое детей. Муж работает охранником на мельничном комбинате. Две дочери живут отдельно, а сын живёт с родителями и помогает по хозяйству. Моркан занимается животноводством и продаёт молоко. Благодаря своему хозяйству Моркан смогла без особых трудностей выдать замуж дочерей и дать им образование. Сейчас Моркан надеется получить кредит и купить ГСМ для вспашки земли. Весной они собираются сеять пшеницу.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Lilia K. is the leader of the loan group. She is 42 years old and lives with her family in Karabalta, a provincial town. Because of unemployment, many residents left town for the capital Bishkek or to go abroad to find work. In these conditions, Lilia and her husband could secure their own work. They are engaged in agriculture. You may know, the local climate and landscape are pleasantly agreeable for raising livestock and agricultural activities. Lilia inherited some livestock and already for the duration of 20 years raising animals has provided them a fundamental source of survival. Owing to the fact that she owns her livestock, Lilia was able to provide her children an education. Their older son is 19 years old. He works in a “pelmeni” (ravioli) shop. The younger son is 17 years old. For the time being, he is at home and is not working. Both Lilia’s sons actively participate in tending the livestock. Therefore, Lilia does not encounter any sort of difficulty in her work. Lilia applied for a loan, in order to purchase gasoline and motor oil for working plots of land in the spring. They want to buy gasoline and motor oil now, because in the spring they will be significantly more expensive. Kamza S. is 52 years old. His wife works as a schoolteacher. Kamza by himself is engaged in a favorite occupation – raising livestock. He similarly sells milk and earns additionally by working plots of land. Kamza and his wife are raising three daughters. Their oldest daughter is 20 years old. Kamza sent her to study in medical school. Kamza hopes to receive a loan and to utilize these resources in buying gasoline and motor oil for working his land. Dildepurus N. is 51 years old. She has three children. Her children are already fully independent. Her eldest daughter is married and lives separately. Her middle daughter works in Bishkek, and the youngest studies at a university. Dildepurus’ husband works as an electrician. Five years ago, Dildepurus opened her own activity. She leased a space in the market and began to offer sewing services. She does restorations and takes orders for individual seamstress jobs. Dildepurus applied for a loan with the goal of buying gasoline and motor oil for plowing the land. Morkan A. is 48 years old. Morkan has three children. Her husband works as a guard in a milling plant. Two daughters live separately and the son lives with his parents and helps with the farm. Morkan raises livestock and sells milk. Thanks to her farming, Morkan is able without particular difficulties to offer her daughters in marriage and provide them with an education. Now, Morkan hopes to receive a loan and purchase gasoline and motor oil for plowing. In the spring, they gather to plant wheat. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy oil to plough the land

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth M. is from the village of Caputol. She is 44 years old. Ruth is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Ruth owns and operates a "habal-habal" (transportation) business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle transport services to local community members. Ruth has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from it.

In 2004, Ruth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruth has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Ruth is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the 21st loan taken out by Ruth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Jyparkul's Group

texts.en:
Jyparkul lives on the outskirts of the city of Balykchi, which means “a fisherman”. To many people, the life in this rural area does not seem to be that attractive. There is an extremely high rate of unemployment in this city. Therefore, many young people have left the city to look for a job in the capital. Nevertheless, Jyparkul and her husband have chosen to stay. Instead of moving to the capital and starting from zero, they have preferred to create opportunities where other people have already dropped their hands.

Jyparkul is 42. She and her husband are happy parents as they have four sons. Their sons' ages range from as young as 5 to 21. Previously they had ten sheep. They invested their savings thriftily and were able to buy cows and calves. After that, they bought horses and started to trade in cattle. Now, the livestock they have include two horses, three cows, four calves and 30 sheep. Due to this business, they have been able to marry their son. Their two elder sons help the parents look after the cattle. So Jyparkul and her husband do not have any difficulties looking after that many cattle. Their monthly income from trading in livestock is up to $230. This is a good income. Jyparkul decided to apply for a loan to purchase seven or eight sheep and a calf. She wants to increase the total population of their livestock in preparation for marrying off the rest of her sons.

Jyparkul is the leader of this group. Jyparkul’s partners are: Nazgul, 36, married, with four children. Nazgul stays at home and feeds up a horse for sale. She needs a loan to buy a foal.

Aibubush, 59, is retired. Together with her husband, she raises cattle. She needs a loan to buy calves to raise.

Aizada, 26, has two children. She stays at home and looks after cattle. They have four cows and ten sheep. Her husband is a taxi driver. Aizada needs a loan to buy a horse to raise for sale.

loans.use: To buy sheep and a calf

loans.name: Jamyikan's Group

texts.en:
Jamyikan is a widow. She is sixty three years old. Jamyikan lives in a city of Balykchi. After her husband’s death, Jamyikan has been living alone as her children are grown-ups and live separately.

Most people of Jamyikan’s age after becoming grandparents prefer to live in their children’s homes. Jamyikan as well, could easily live at her children’s expense. But, Jamyikan has never asked her children for help. She does not depend on her children. Moreover, at many times she helps her daughter financially and always cares about her children.

To make a living Jamyikan trades in dishes. She purchases different kinds of dishes: ceramic dishes, dinner sets and porcelain.

Jamyikan is an experienced businesswoman. She used to trade in various convenience goods as long ago as when she was young. Then she applied for a job and started to work for Government. After the retirement, the pension appeared to be too little to sustain a decent living. So Jamyikan did not hesitate and invested all her early savings, about 70$ in purchasing dishes. She returned to her former occupation of trade.

Now, she cannot afford a big scale trade. Nevertheless, her engagement brings her a stable income of 65-75$ each month. Jamyikan has applied for this loan to invest it in purchasing different kinds of dinner sets, porcelain, etc. as the New Year is approaching, when many people organize grand arrangements, feasts and buy dishes as New Year’s gifts. Jamyikan has three partners:
Mairamkul, 53, is a widow and has a son. She sells women’s clothes and hosiery. Her monthly income is around 45$. Mairamkul needs a loan to purchase winter clothes for sale.

Raisa, 38, has four children. Her husband works as a driver. To support her family, Raisa trades in silver and gold. She hopes to obtain this loan and import silver from Turkey and India.

Anarkan, 46, is divorced. She has a retired mother and an unemployed sister. Anarkan works as a seller in a bookstore. Anarkan’s salary, is just 12$ a month. Her mother's pension is 80$. Anarkan needs a loan to buy a calf.

loans.use: To buy dinner sets to sell for people for New Year parties

loans.name: Bakyara Tutungukye Group, Ibanda

texts.en: K. Jesca has a retail shop and a restaurant in Rwomuhoro Trading Centre that she has been running for ten years. She is a hardworking and devoted married lady with seven children. The oldest is at university and she also cares for two orphans. She started with a very small shop which has now grown substantially. She has been able to attract many customers because she treats them well and has enough stock that is in demand. She has a goal of expanding her shop further so that she can increase her profit to continue educating her children and expanding her business further. Jesca needs this loan to be able to buy more sugar, soap, salt and cooking oil for her shop and foodstuffs for the restaurant.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop and buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Ariston

texts.en:
Ariston L. is from the village of Poblacion, Catarman, Camiguin Province. He is 51 years old. Ariston is married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Ariston owns and operates a business venture in the food sector: operating a fishing business. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Ariston has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Ariston joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ariston has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. Ariston is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Ariston from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to supplement the income of his family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Jessica is married and her husband is a farmer with plantations, cows and goats with a family livestock enclosure. Jessica needs a loan to be able to recapitalize her businesses.

loans.name: Kigando Tubinge Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en: Zefuliya T.  is 36 years old and married with three children aged 12 years, 3 years and 6 months. The older two children are in school.  For the past two years he has been in the business of producing and selling in Kigando  making 50,000 weekly profit. Zeuliya says that his business is mostly affected by the poor and expensive transportation system. Since Zeuliya is a farmer himself, he is able to make good profits from his sales and some of his goals are to start exporting the produce and educating all his children. He needs a loan to be able to injcrease his produce so that he can increase his sales. He is such a hard working and friendly man.

loans.use: Increase his produce.

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en: Batjargal is 41-year-old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Batjargal sells dairy products at the Narantuul market, the largest outdoor market in the city. She does the business with her husband and their oldest daughter. Although her daughter goes to a local university, she helps in her parents' business whenever she gets some time. Batjargal purchases various dairy products, including cheese, curds, and milk cream from Bayanhongor province, where she and her husband were born. She said that it is easier and more convenient to purchase dairy products from the people they know. She has been selling dairy products for almost two decades at the market and has many repeat customers. Her husband usually goes to the countryside to purchase dairy products and she  sells the products at the market. She says that this business is the main source of her family income and she would like to expand her business as capital allows. Batjargal says that she and her husband hope to see their two children grow up well and obtain a good education. She requests a loan to purchase more dairy products for his family business.

loans.use: to purchase more dairy products

To make a living, Razel owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Razel has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Razel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Razel is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Razel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Daajinsuren

texts.en:
Daajinsuren T. is a 46 year-old single mother and currently lives with her two daughters in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her oldest daughter goes to a local university. Daajinsuren moved from the countryside to the city after her husband's death four years ago. 

After she came to the city with her two daughters, she started a small retail business. She started selling children's clothes at the Narantuul market, the largest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar. Since 2009, she moved to the Sunday indoor shopping mall where she now sells various women's and men's clothes. Her daughter helps in her business whenever she gets some time. In the near future, she hopes to rent one more stall as her business expands. 

Her dream is to make sure her two daughters receive good educations and pursue their dreams. She requests a loan to purchase more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes so that she can serve her customers.

Servanda owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Servanda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. Servanda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. Teresito is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be his 2nd from HSPFI. loans.name: Nyamtogtoh

texts.en:
Nyamtogtoh P. lives with her husband and her 13-year-old son in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her son is a secondary school student and her husband helps in her business.

Nyamtogtoh rents a small stall in Hantalst shopping center in the city and sells various CDs and DVDs at her stall. Before starting her own business, she used to be a saleswoman in a local company. In 2008, she decided to start her own small business with help from her husband to utilize her experience.

Nyamtogtoh’s CD and DVD retailing business has been quite good since the start and, with the profit, she has already started building a small building on the land her family owns. She would like to have her family store where she hopes to retail many types of products.

After the shopping center closes, Nyamtogtoh and her husband use their small car as a taxi in the city, in order to earn extra income. She says that she works hard with her husband to make her family's life better. She requests a loan to purchase more CDs and DVDs for her retail stall.

loans.use: To purchase more CDs and DVDs

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna M. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Myrna owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Myrna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. loans.name: Munhtuul

texts.en:
Munhtuul A., 38, lives with her elderly parents and her 15-year-old daughter, a secondary school student, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Munhtuul has a small business retailing traditional snuff bottles. Snuff bottles are a part of the local culture, and people carry them, especially during national celebrations, and use them while greeting other locals. She sells various precious stone stuff bottles imported from Ereen, China - a border town from which many inexpensive Chinese products are imported. Munhtuul's brother also makes snuff-bottles, which gives them a competitive advantage over others.

Now requesting a loan to purchase more bottles for her business, Munhtuul says that her goal is to build a small house for her family, as she wants them to live in a warm shelter.

loans.use: To purchase more snuff-bottles

loans.name: Tsetsgee

texts.en:
Tsetsgee J. is 53 years old and a single mother of four children. She currently lives with three of her children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband passed away four years ago. Her oldest daughter just got married and now lives with her own family. 

Tsetsgee sells various souvenirs and cards that she makes. She makes very appealing and cute souvenirs, including cards and small souvenirs with faux pearls. People like buying her cards and souvenirs. Her daughter helps in her business whenever she has time. 

Tsesgee purchases the accessories and pearls from Ereen, China - a border town from which inexpensive Chinese products are imported. She hopes to earn more profit from her business so she can finance her second daughter's upcoming wedding.

She is requesting a loan to purchase accessories for her business.

loans.name: Bathuu

texts.en:
Bathuu P. is 39-year-old. He lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. His daughter is 15 years old and student in a local secondary school and his son is 6 years old and goes to a local kindergarten. 

Bathuu has a degree in mechanical engineering from a local university. With the degree, he worked for a local company as a refrigerator and freezer engineer from 1996 and 2000. However, in 2001, he decided to start his own business and now fixes refrigerators and freezers for those who call and order his services. He has already obtained some contracts from local companies as a refrigerator engineer. He hopes to expand his business and create his own refrigerator repair company. 

He is requesting a loan to buy parts and supplies to repair refrigerators and freezers.

loans.use: To buy parts and supplies to repair refrigerators and freezers.

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is a 60 year old widow with eight children. Four of her children go to school. Norah also takes care of additional family members. She owns and lives in a four-room house with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.  

Norah sells charcoal from her store in Naguru. She buys the charcoal locally so she doesn’t incur transportation costs. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala  She works seven days a week .She receives an average of 50 customers a day and sells both wholesale and retail to all types of people. 

Her most significant monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for her children. Her major business challenges is the rainy season which make it difficult for customers to reach her because she works in a muddy place. 

She has been in this business for twenty years and a member of MCDT for eight years. She is now borrowing her nineteenth loan. Norah joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She wants to see her business grower bigger and she wants to sell only in wholesale quantities.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Tuvdenjargal

texts.en:
L. Tuvdenjargal is 44 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Gobi-Altai, Mongolia. They live together in a "ger," which is a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His daughters, ages 18 and 14, attend a local secondary school. 

Tuvdenjargal makes furniture and other wooden products in his town. He designs and crafts the furniture himself. Tuvdenjargal started his business in 1994 after working as a carpenter for several years. He graduated from college in 1984 as a carpenter and has used his experience to develop a successful business. He produces high quality products and is an experienced craftsman. 

Tuvdenjargal is a hardworking businessman and is known for his pleasant personality. He is focused on the future and hopes to continue to improve his business. He says, “I need to save money to support my children's education.” He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug ($700 USD) loan to purchase wood for his business.

loans.use: To purchase wood for his furniture business

loans.name: Santa Elisa Group

texts.es:
La Srta. Rosmery tiene 31 años desde muy jovencita vendía verduras en un puesto del mercado junto a su abuelita a quien ayudaba, pero al ver que su padre y sus tíos fabricaban seguros de puertas (cerraduras, candados, cerrojos) ella decide iniciarse en ese negocio pero ofreciéndolos directamente a los comerciantes ferreteros. al principio su timidez fue una barrera, pero con el pasar del tiempo logro consolidarse  logrando que los hombres que son la mayoría de sus clientes puedan confiar en ella.
 Rosmery tiene muchos clientes y su negocio cada día crece, actualmente reparte sus productos al por mayor, con  sus ganancias ha logrado adquirir 3 puestos de venta en una galería, los que esta construyendo poco a poco, tiene en mente para el futuro importar maquinarias para convertirse en fabricante de lo que ahora vende, con el préstamo de EDAPROSPO terminara la construcción de uno de sus puestos de venta, entre sus planes para el futuro esta  seguir progresando, quiere convertirse en una empresaria de éxito. Por eso ella se prepara y le gusta asistir  capacitaciones y conferencias sobre empresas para lograr todo lo que quiere.


*La Señorita Rosmery es la de casaca marron y chompa roja
texts.en:
Srta. Rosmery is 31 years old and had been selling vegetables since a very young age. She managed a market stand with her grandmother working as her assistant. When her father and uncles started manufacturing security devices (locks, padlocks, and bolts), she decided to get into the business of selling these products directly to hardware merchants. At first she had to overcome her shyness, but over time she successfully stood firm with the men who make up the majority of her customers and now have confidence in her. Rosemery has many customers and her business continues to grow each day. She currently distributes her products wholesale. With the earnings she generated, she was able to acquire three vending posts at a shopping center. As she continues to gradually build her business, Rosmery has plans in the future to import machinery for manufacturing the same products that she currently sells. With her loan from EDAPROSPO, Rosemery will complete construction of one her vending stalls. She wants to continue progressing and become a successful entrepreneur. Rosmery prepares herself by attending seminars and business conferences so that she can achieve everything she wants. *Srta. Rosmery is the woman wearing the red sweater and brown jacket.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finish construction of a vending post

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
D. Altantsetseg is 56 years old. She lives with her husband and daughter in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Altantsetseg  and her family live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger." Her husband is retired and collects a pension of 123,000 tugrugs (~$80 USD) every month. Her daughter is 23 years old and recently graduated college with a degree in clothing design. 

Altantsetseg and her daughter are seamstresses. They design and produce a variety of clothes to meet their customer's needs. Altantsetseg started her business in 1999. She has built a stable business over the last 10 years and has become an experienced clothing designer and seamstress. Currently, she has two sewing machines to keep up with her quick growing business. She is a very motivated woman and works hard to improve her business and support her family. 

Altantsetseg is requesting a 450,000 tugrug loan to purchase fabric and supplies so she can make dresses for the upcoming New Year holiday.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and supplies for her clothing design business

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Altantsetseg L. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Zavkhan Province in Western Mongolia. She and her family live in a "ger," which is a yurt or traditional Mongolian housing tent. Both of her sons currently attend a local secondary school. 

Altantsetseg grows and sells vegetables in her town. She started her business in 1995. She has gained much experience as a vegetable grower over the years and has built a stable business operation. Today, she has many customers that like her locally grown vegetables. Altantsetseg is a very open-minded and hard-working woman. She has proven herself to be a trustworthy borrower and hopes to continue her success in the future. 

She says, “I have received loans from XacBank before that have helped me to improve my business. I hope to continue my success with my new loan.” 

Altantsetseg is requesting a 200,000 tugrug ($150 USD) loan to purchase beets, carrots, and cabbage, and several uncommon vegetables, to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase beets, carrots and cabbage

loans.name: Ariuntuya

texts.en:
Ariuntuya R. lives with her husband and three children in Zavkhan Province in Western Mongolia. She and her family live in a "ger," which is a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. All three of her children currently attend a local secondary school. Her husband operates a coal transport business in which he uses his truck to haul coal. 

Ariuntuya sells meat in her town. She started her business in 1996 with capital of 500,000 tugrugs (~$350 USD) and has built a successful operation over the years. She has expanded her customer base and gained much experience at running her business. Today, her working capital exceeds 1,500,000 tugrugs (~$1050 USD) and she has used her earnings to purchase a car for her family. Ariuntuya is a very open-minded businesswoman who strives to operate her business efficiently and in a clean environment. 

She is focused on the future and says, “One can achieve a goal with hard work.” 

Ariuntuya is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug ($1725 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of meat. She will store the meat and sell it when supplies are short next spring.

loans.use: to purchase a large amount of meat

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji M. sells various items in her shop, such as sugar, salt, books, and rice. She is requesting a loan to purchase other items for her retail shop .  Keji is 30 years old and is married to a soldier. She has 4 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open another retail shop in a market.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy items to sell

loans.name: Chhich(Thach)

texts.en: Mrs. S., 39, is a local vegetable seller who started her business at the market in 2000. She is married to Mr. Py, 55, who is a staff member working in industry. This couple has been married for many years and is blessed with two young children. One grown child is married and lives separately, while other one is a single person who currently raises animals to earn a living. Since many years ago, the family’s house has been damaged, and their standard of living has been affected. Because of this, S. needs to borrow a loan from Kiva to be used to repair her old house. She proposes to use the rest of the loan to sustain her business growth. (S. and her husband are in the picture above.)

loans.use: To repair her old house.

loans.name: Janipher Ngamita ‘S Group

texts.en:
Janepher is a 27-year-old married woman with three children between the ages of 3 - 9 years. All of her children go to school. Janepher takes care of additional family members. She owns a three-room house where she lives with five people. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.  

Janepher owns a stall in Nakawa Market where she sells second-hand clothes. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She buys the second hand clothes at the Owino Market, so she has to pay to transport the clothes to her stall. Janepher works seven days a week .She receives an average of 30 customers a day and sells retail and wholesale to all types of people. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding her family, school fees for her children, and rent for her business premises. 

In addition to her clothing business, she also owns a retail shop in the same area. Her major business challenge is the rainy season which makes it difficult for customers to reach her because she works in a muddy place. 

She has been in this business for four years and an MCDT member for two years. She is now requesting her fourth loan. Janepher joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more second-hand clothes and merchandise for her retail shop. She wants to see her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more second-hand clothes and merchandise for her retail shop

loans.name: Warlita

texts.en:
Warlita M. is from the village of Temogsay Bug-ong, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old. Warlita is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Warlita buys and sells coconuts in the local community. Warlita has been in this business for over six years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.  

This loan will be the third taken out by Warlita from HSPFI. Most recently, Warlita has repaid a loan of 6,000 PHP. Warlita is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Lilit

texts.en:
Lilit G. is from Iligan City.  She is 25 years old, married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, Lilit owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, mainly selling food and daily use products in the local community.  Lilit has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lilit joined HSPFI to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business. Lilit is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue to improve/expand her business. 
-------------------------------
About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Nyongle

texts.en:
Nyongle V. is currently in the business of selling beer and local alcohol and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer and bags of charcoal to sell. Nyongle is 29 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more crates of beer and bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Hau's Group

texts.en:
Hậu Thị Tạ is 56 years old. ( id: 010114140011). She is a farmer. She also has a store in the market where she sells noodle soup, vermicelli, etc. She lives in Tuan Le village, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. Her children are married, but she has to earn money for her life. She has a monthly income of about 2.500.000 VND. She has taken part in Binhminh MicroFinance Program for 5 years and always repays her loan on time. This time, she wants to borrow 7.630.000 VND ( or 412 USD) to invest in her business.

The other borrower with her is: Hanh Thị Đoàn (id: 010114140024), 61 years old. She wants to borrow 4.578.000 vnd ( or 245 USD) to breed chickens and grow vegetables.

loans.use: to invest in her business

loans.name: Melchora

texts.en:
Melchora H. is from the village of Iligan City. She is 30 years old. Melchora is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Melchora owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Melchora has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melchora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melchora is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Melchora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Baasanjav

texts.en:
Baasanjav D. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and five children in a house in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. Her oldest son is a university student, her second son and both of her daughters attend secondary school and her youngest son is one year old. Her husband currently works as a construction worker during the summer and looks after the children during the winter.

Baasanjav operates a small grocery business from a booth in her town. She is a cook by trade but runs the grocery in her spare time to supplement her income. Her business is very important to her and she says, "I must work hard to feed my big family.” She is requesting a loan of 400,000 tugrug to purchase grocery products for her business and make repairs to her house.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products for her business and to repair her house

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a 70 year widow with four children aged between 42 and 48 years. None of her children go to school. She owns a three room house where she lives with five people. Halima takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and running water and gets three meals a day. 


Halima doesn’t incur transport costs to and from the charcoal villages because she buys from her home from delivery vans which bring the charcoal from the villages. She works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week, receiving an average of 30 customers a day and selling to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her grandchildren. Her major business challenges are seasonality and the rainy season which hinders her customers from coming to her because she works from an open space. 


She has been in this business for 30 years, and with MCDT for eight years during which she has had 20 loans. Halima joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She wants to see her business grow bigger so that she can start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for resale

loans.name: Badamjav

texts.en:
Badamjav G. is 59 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in the Gobi-Altai province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent called a "ger". Her older daughter is 25 years old and helps with the family business and her younger daughter is a university student. Her husband is disabled and currently unemployed.

Badamjav operates a dairy products trading business in her town. She sells a variety of local dairy products to her many customers. Badamjav started her business in 2003 and has built a stable operation over the years. She is a very hardworking woman and is focused on supporting her family. She says, “My business is our only source of income because my husband cannot work.” Badamjav hopes to soon buy a stall at the local market at which to sell her dairy products. She is requesting a 1,600,000 tugrug loan to purchase dairy products in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase dairy products for her business

loans.name: Jessielyn

texts.en: Jessielyn M. is from the village of Cabu-an, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 25 years old. Jessielyn is married and has 3 young children. To make a living, Jessielyn owns & operates a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling coconut in the local community. Jessielyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Jessielyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessielyn is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & for working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jessielyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. loans.name: Emma

texts.en:

While this is not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes primarily from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp in the local community. Emma has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the firstt loan taken out by Emma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business.

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: Mrs. Chum That is 59 years old and a resident of Kampong Chhnang province, where she and her husband make a living farming rice. Beside their farm work, the family also goes to shovel sand in and around the lakes to sell for extra income. The older couple now has three married and three single children. Almost all of their children are employed at different occupations. In the past, Chum That has rented a boat to use as transportation for the sand sales that is part of her business activity. To reduce the hiring fee, she hopes to own a boat but she has no money yet to buy one. That is why she requested a loan from Kiva through HKL.

loans.use: To buy a boat.

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
T. Batbayar is 46 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Tuv province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His oldest son is a construction worker and his two daughters both attend a local secondary school. 

Batbayar currently works as a security guard at the local army post and also drives a taxi. He primarily drives a taxi and only works at the army post seven days each month. Batbayar started his business in 2006. He is very hardworking person and is known for his good personality. He has become an experienced and trusted driver and has used his business to stabilize his income. Batbayar is working hard for the future and says, “I am planning hope to improve my taxi service.” He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan to refurbish his car.

loans.use: to refurbish his car

loans.name: Laurencia

texts.en:
Laurencia S. is from the village of Magting, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Laurencia is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Laurencia owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling vegestables in the local community. Laurencia has been involved in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Laurencia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laurencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. Laurencia is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Laurencia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Ofelya

texts.en: Ofelya was born in 1958. She is married and has two daughters who are married and live on their own. Ofelya lives with her husband in the town of Ijevan. She worked as an accountant in one of Ijevan's factory for many years prior to its liquidation. Since 2004, she and her husband have made a living selling bouquets and wreaths from stall they rent in the town market. Thanks to the success of this business, Ofelya has been able to repair her house and pay for daughters’ education and weddings. She likes her work because it allows her to hear many romantic stories related to her bouquets. Ofelya has applied for a loan for 900,000 AMD to buy a big lot of flowers from which she will make compositions for sale. She plans to spend the expected income made possible by this loan to enlarge her shop.

loans.use: To buy a large lot of flowers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw materials such as goat and sheep skin

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
Milly P. lives in the village of San Jose, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 53 years old, married and has one adult-aged child. She makes a living by running a sari-sari (or variety) retail store where she sells a range of different products to people in her local community. She has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2008, Milly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid two loans for 7,000 PHP each from HSPFI. Milly has applied for a new loan of 8,000 PHP to buy new items to sell and expand her product offerings. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to improve her family's living conditions. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Tosmaa

texts.en: D. Tosmaa is 60 years old and lives with her husband in Khovd province in western Mongolia. She and her husband live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger." With help from her husband, Tosmaa runs a small cafe in her town. She provides a variety of traditional Mongolian meals to her many customers. She and her husband opened their cafe in 1996 and have built a stable operation over the years. They are well known in their community and have many loyal customers. The couple has used their earnings to pay their children's tuition and hope to build a new house next year. Tosmaa says, “We are doing our best to have nice and happy life.” She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan to buy meat to store for the winter (when supplies get short) and firewood for heating.

loans.use: to buy meat to store for the winter and firewood

loans.name: Teofila

texts.en:
Teofila P. lives in the village of Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 56 years old, married, has six school-aged children and makes a living by selling seafood. She has been in this business for more than five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Teofila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is applying for her first loan, for 5,000 PHP, to buy additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Manibazar

texts.en:
Manibazar L. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and four children in the Gobi-Altai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a "ger", which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His oldest two children are university students and his youngest two attend a local secondary school.

Manibazar and his wife, Nansalmaa, operate both a vegetable trading and a cellphone business in their town. His wife is responsible for managing their vegetable business and Manibazar sells cellphones. Manibazar started his businesses in 2007 with a loan received from XacBank, Kiva's Mongolian MFI partner. Before opening his cellphone trading business, he used to sell phone cards for Mobicom, one of the largest telephone operators in Mongolia.

Manibazar and his wife are both working hard to improve their businesses. Their earnings have enabled them to provide a good life for their children. Manibazar says, “I want to be able to afford my children's education and help them to become good people.” He is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase cellphones and phone parts for his business and vegetables for his wife's business.

loans.use: To purchase cellphones for his business

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites L. is from District 2, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 30 years old. Marites is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from preparing "longganisa" (pork sausages) for sale. Marites has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 1000 PHP weekly. In 2008, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the third loan taken out by Marites from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by the business to supplement the family's income.

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Rogelyn

texts.en:
Rogelyn P. is from the village of Gumbil, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old, is married, and has one infant child.

Rogelyn engages in hog-fattening. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rogelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets.

Rogelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and vitamins. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Uranchimeg

texts.en:
Uranchimeg is 39 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent. All three of her sons, aged 16, 14, and 11, attend a local secondary school. 

Uranchimeg operates a beauty-product retail business in a rented stall at a local market. She began her business in 2000 and since then, she has stabilized her business operation and gained a lot of experience running a business. She would like to grow her business in the future and expand her customer base. Uranchimeg is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount and wider variety of beauty products for her growing business.

loans.name: Badamtsetseg

texts.en: Badamtsetseg is 45 years old and lives with her three children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband works in a foreign country and sends 150,000-250,000 tugrug (~100-200 USD) per month in order to help them with their living expenses. Her two daughters and son all attend a local secondary school while Badamtsetseg operates a grocery retail business near her home. She began her business in 2001 by operating a small booth. At that time, her working capital was 100,000-150,000 tugrug (~70-105 USD). Since then, she has been able to move from her small booth into a shop and now her working capital is between 300,000 and 500,000 tugrug (~210-350 USD). Her business is the main source of family income and she attributes her success to her good accounting and financial skills. She says, “I want my children to be better educated people who can contribute to their country’s development.” Badamtsetseg is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan in order to purchase a large variety of grocery products for her shop.

loans.use: to purchase a large variety of grocery products

loans.name: Boaz

texts.en: Boaz O. is a 53 year old man, married and blessed with 8 children. Boaz used to run a bakery before he ventured into dairy farming. Boaz is a proud owner of 3 dairy cattle, which is an achievement in his local area; this is because farmers in this part of the country are widely known as sugarcane specialists. He takes his milk daily to the nearby town of Butula, Busia District. He says he will use this loan to expand his dairy shed and prepare more feed since one of the cows is pregnant and due to deliver soon. Boaz would like a loan of KShs. 30,000.

loans.use: To expand his dairy shed and buy more feed

loans.name: Ayoko

texts.fr:
En 2007, cette dame a ouvert sa propre boutique dans laquelle elle fait du commerce de détail, après un an d’activité, elle dispose d’une clientèle considérable, tellement qu'elle doit augmenter son stock pour pouvoir tous les satisfaire. C’est pour cette raison qu’elle s’est adressé à WAGES pour obtenir un crédit et augmenter son stock avec 2 postes télévisions, une machine à laver et 4 baffles.
elle est célibataire et c’est avec son revenu qu’elle subvient à ses charges.
texts.en:
In 2007 this woman opened her own shop in which she exercises a retail activity; after a year of business she has built up a significant customer base, to the extent that she needs to increase her stock in order to satisfy them all. It is for this reason that she has approached WAGES in order to get a loan to increase her stock with two televisions, a washing machine and 4 loudspeakers. She is single and uses her income to cover her expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of televisions, washing machine and loudspeakers

He currently has a tender with the local schools that are putting up new classrooms and as a result he would like to use a loan of KShs. 30, 000 along with his own funds to effect this transaction.

loans.name: Batchuluun

texts.en:
Batchuluun is 52 years old and lives with her husband and five adult children in the Zavkhan province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic tent. All of her children either work or attend university or secondary school. Her husband and her second daughter, Dashmaa, both help Batchuluun with her hair salon business.

She began her salon in 1990 after working as a hairdresser for another salon. Because she has operated for almost 20 years in her community, Batchuluun has gained a loyal customer base and respect in the business community. She competes in the Hair Style Competition every year and hopes to win in the upcoming year. Batchuluun is requesting an 800,000 tugrug (~560 USD) loan in order to purchase tools and hair styling materials for her salon.

A client of LAPO, an organization committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa, she is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. Rose says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Cette femme s’est spécialisée depuis 2003 dans la vente de sucre qu'elle emballe dans les sachets, elle s’approvisionne à Lomé dans la ville de tsévié, elle fait face en ce moment à une rupture de stock, voulant se réapprovisionner elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 15 sac de sucres.
étant mariée et mère de 04 enfants, elle apporte sa contribution financière dans son foyer grâce à cette activité qu'elle exerce.
texts.en:
This woman has since 2003 specialised in the sale of sugar which she packs up in sachets; she stocks up at Lomé in the town of Tsévié. At the moment she has no stock left and since she wants to rebuild her stock she is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy 15 bags of sugar. Married with four children, she makes a financial contribution to her household from this business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

He began his business in 2004 with the help of his father and after his father retired, he began operating the business on his own.
