While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Evelyn earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Evelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Evelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Purita

texts.en:
Purita is a 54-year old woman, married and blessed with 3 children. They are currently living at Lagundi, Morong Rizal, Philippines. She is also a woman of strong faith to overcome all challenges to achieve her dreams.

In 2000, she joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap Inc.) a microfinance institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. As a member of ASHI for almost nine years, she has shown very good performance in her credit rating (basis of loans); therefore, she is being trusted by the institution to acquire larger loans.

She runs a variety store with a frozen foods section and also a little carenderia (ready-to-eat food). She started her variety store through her initiative and knowledge of dealing with customers. Her business is growing because the people in her neighborhood like her products and find what they need in her store instead of going to the town proper. She is requesting a loan of PHP 45,000.00 to use for additional capital to improve her business and her income.

She dreams of growing her variety store into a mini-grocery store and expanding it to other places. Her children are her inspiration to pursue her variety store business. She hopes that this business will be the source of income to finance the needs of her family and to have a comfortable house to live in. Purita now feels very happy about her work and the service of ASHI and Kiva. It offers her big opportunities to make her dreams come true. She is grateful to ASHI for supporting people like her who want to work and get ahead. She hopes that they continue this way for a long time and help many families and enterprising women.

loans.use: to buy a variety of goods for her general store, including frozen foods and ready-to-eat food

loans.name: Samir

texts.en: Samir R. is 26 years old. He is a young trader who sells seasonal fruits and vegetables. He uses his father’s car to go to the local farmers to purchase seasonal fruits and vegetables and afterwards, takes them to the most crowded street of Imishli city to start selling them. He also has a place in the center bazaar, but he goes there every second day of the week. This type of business is very profitable and, at the same time, very hard. Samir wakes up at 5 a.m. to go to the local farmers and by 9 a.m. he usually begins his sales. He enjoys his work because he is very sociable. Samir is married and has three children. He works for welfare of his family and to improve their living conditions. He has applied for a 1600 AZN loan.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise.

loans.name: Rotchelyn

texts.en: Rotchelyn E. is from the village of Pan-ay, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 25 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Rotchelyn owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rotchelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet O. is a widow living with three of her grandchildren in Malanga village, Busia district. She is also the sole owner of a business of selling deep-fried fish. She is also venturing into small-scale tea planting.

Violet is a formal civil service servant, and her future dream is to guarantee education for the young ones with whom she lives. She would like a loan of 20,000 KES, which she says she will invest in the fish business and also start a grocery stall right next to her frying place at the market. This, she says, increases her chance for more profit which will go to pay the school fees for one of her grandchildren.

loans.use: Increase stock and venture into grocery sellilng.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine G. is from the village of Cabaruan. She is 28 years old. Josephine is married. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Josephine has been engaged in her business for several years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase young livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Josephine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase young livestock to raise and sell in future.

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

Roseline is married with two children and she is 44 years old. She sells crates of drinks at retail prices to her customers and has been in this business for five years. She hopes to be a drink distributor in the future.

Roseline is happy because the festive season is here and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She needs a loan of NGN 40,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Damiranjav

texts.en: Damiranjav is 38 years old and lives with his spouse and three children in the Khovd province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest son attends university and his two younger children, 10 and 4, attend a local secondary school. Damiranjav operates a local transportation service in his town where he not only transports people, but also coal and firewood. He began his business in 2006 with his own truck and is planning on continuing in this business for the future in order to provide for his children’s education. Damiranjav is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1,400 USD) loan in order to purchase replacement parts for his truck and for his oldest son’s tuition fees.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for a truck used in transportation business.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is a 32-year-old married mother of one. She operates a boutique business in Dandora estate in Nairobi where she sells ladies', men's and children's clothing. She says that her business is well-stocked and at a strategic place. Mercy has requested a loan of KES 80,000 to build a house in Ruiru. She hopes to open an exhibition in Nairobi and start importing clothes. She describes herself as God-fearing, sociable, courteous and a woman of integrity.

loans.use: To build a house.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is forty-two years old. She is married and has six children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Comfort is a baker. She bakes bread and supplies it to retailers and beverage sellers. She has been in business for over twenty years and would like a loan to buy bags of flour and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour for use in bakery.

loans.name: Ayoko

texts.fr: Cette femme est une femme qui exerce depuis 2004 le commerce de pagnes, elle a associé plus tard à ce commerce la vente de produits de beauté. En période de fêtes de fin d’année la demande de pagnes et de produits de beauté est très élevée parce que les femmes aiment se faire belle en cette période. Elle voudrait profiter de cette opportunité pour accroître ses recettes raison pour laquelle elle sollicite un prêt de WAGES pour acheter 20 pagnes de diverses qualités, 4 cartons de crème « VIT-FEE » et 10 mèches.
texts.en:
This woman has, since 2004, had a business selling "pagnes" (a West African term for brightly coloured fabric); she has since combined this business with the sale of beauty products. During the holiday period at the end of the year the demand for "pagnes" and beauty products is very high because women want to make themselves beautiful during this period. She would like to take advantage of this opportunity to increase her income and it is for this reason that she is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy 20 "pagnes" of varying quality, 4 boxes of "VIT-FEE" cream and ten hair extensions.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothes and beauty products

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita A. is from the village of Cabaruan. She is 48 years old. Pacita is married with children. To make a living, Pacita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Pacita has been engaged in her business for several years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Pacita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pacita is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Pacita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is 69 years old. She is widowed and has given birth to eight children, some of whom are still in school. She lives with some of her children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people there. 

Janet is a trader. She trades in cereals such as maize, rice, beans, etc. She buys from nearby communities and treks to sell in nearby towns. She has been in this business for 10 years and wants a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Gelly

texts.en: Gelly B. is from the village of Cabuan, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is years old. Gelly is widowed and has three young children. To make a living, Gelly runs a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Gelly has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month from these activities. In 2008, Gelly joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gelly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Gelly is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Gelly from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Ganbold

texts.en:
Ganbold is 48 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Dornogobi province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic tent. His three sons all attend a local secondary school while Ganbold manages a car-repair service near his home. He began his business in 2003 by building a garage in his yard and with several years of successful operation, he has a large customer base and can now handle almost any repair work that a customer needs. 

Because of his mechanic skills, he has also been able to build a car from scratch and would like to soon make trips to customers’ homes in order to grow his business. Ganbold is requesting a 700,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase repair parts for his own car so that he can travel to his customers’ homes.

loans.use: To purchase repair parts

loans.name: Consulacion

texts.en:
Consulacion S. is from the village of South Western Poblacion, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 51 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children.

Consulacion owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Consulacion joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be his first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 


About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

location.town: South Western Poblacion Calamba Mis. Occ

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda Dave is a 48-year old married woman who lives in the village of Barangay Carabalan Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. Her family depends on the income from her general store, from the pig fattening business and from rice farming.

Luzminda’s husband, Rodolfo, is a farmer. They have 7 children who are between 7 and 28 years of age. One of her children is a high school graduate and helps in their business. The other children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Luzminda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 in the hopes that she would be able to assist her husband to improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by opening a general store, engaging in pig fattening and farming rice. Now, she earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,000 from her business activities.

Luzminda is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 13,000 was used to fund operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now, she is borrowing, for her 7th cycle loan, the amount of PHP 14,000. She intends to use this loan to buy fertilizer for the rice farm and towards her general store. Luzminda is working hard to achieve her the dreams and aspirations she has for her family. She wishes to provide her family with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon; (a Hiligaynon  word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them "Dungganon"- a title of esteem  that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for general store and fertilizer for rice farm.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma T. is a 54-year old married woman who lives in Benlot Barangay Poblacion Sta Catalina, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by selling food products like banana chips, coconut bars, etc. and they have a mini bakery.

Elma’s husband, Alejandro, is a baker. They have 3 children who currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. Elma and her husband plan to expand their bakery business and to cater to the needs of the nearby villages and towns.

Elma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 in the hopes that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in the selling of food products that they made and by developing their bakery. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 38,000 from her business activities.

Elma is a member in good standing. Her previous loan, of PHP 19,500, was used to fund the operations of her food production business, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing, for her 11th cycle loan, the amount of PHP 19,500. She intends to use this loan on her bakery and on food production. Elma is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them “Dungganon” - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community, who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Ganchimeg

texts.en:
Ganchimeg is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in a wooden house in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her two daughters, aged 10 and 6, both attend a local secondary school while her husband operates a taxi service in town.

Ganchimeg operates a grocery shop near her home which she inherited from her mother. When the business began, her mother operated out of a small booth which was passed down to Ganchimeg. Since getting the business in 2002, Ganchimeg has successfully expanded it and grown it into a full shop. Now, she not only sells grocery items, but also coal and firewood which are used as fuels in order to heat her customers’ homes.

Currently Ganchimeg earns between 400,000 and 500,000 tugrugs (~280-350 USD) per month and attributes her business success to her good accounting skills.

Ganchimeg would like to keep expanding her shop in the future and is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount of food supplies, coal and firewood for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of food supplies, coal and firewood

loans.name: Atieno Edewa

texts.en:
Atieno Edewa O. is a 54-year-old woman, a widow and the sole guardian of one grandchild in Malanga, Busia district. She is a former fish-seller at Malanga market, where she now runs her grocery business.

She would like a loan of 20,000 KES to increase her stock and to introduce a cooking/frying oil business alongside the grocery. As a former fish seller, she says oil is the highest selling commodity in the area due to fish being a staple food.

Her future dream is ensure the education of her grandchild.

loans.use: To increase grocery stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Carmela

texts.en:
Carmela C. is from the town of Quezon, San Isidro. She is 19 years old, married, and has one infant child.

Carmela owns and operates a business venture into raising ducks for sale. She earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Carmela joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for business improvement. This loan will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for business improvement

loans.name: Ganzorig

texts.en:
Ganzorig is 27 years old and lives with his wife and two-year-old daughter in a house in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Ganzorig’s brother gave him his house and shop building when he left the country in order to work in a foreign country. Ganzorig took the shop building and opened a grocery store there in 2007 with working capital of 6,000,000 tugrugs (~4140 USD). Since he began his business, his monthly earnings have increased to between 300,000 and 350,000 tugrugs (~205-240 USD) and he has been able to purchase furniture for his home. He would eventually like to purchase an apartment where his family would be more comfortable.

Ganzorig is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase groceries for his growing business.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for his business

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia R. is a 43 years old and the mother of five children; only the youngest is still single and the rest of the siblings have their own families. Her husband, Herardo, is a fisherman. She worked very hard to raise her big family. Despite the many difficulties she encountered, she was able to send all their children to school which is one fulfillment of her dreams.

In 2005, with the desire of having supplementary capital for her fishing business, Amalia came up with the idea of joining ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), a Kiva partner in the Philippines. She applied for this loan of Php 20,000 to buy assorted raw materials for her business like fishing net, bamboo, fingerlings (baby fish), etc.

Amalia’s business is one big help in sustaining their daily needs because it provides them with good earnings and she wants to continue the business and will make more investments in it. She dreams of putting up a bigger fish cage in the future and of being able to get a stall in the market for selling her fish.

ASHI is their partner in fulfilling their dreams to fight against poverty and giving them faith in changing their lives. She is very motivated to develop her business towards sustainability because the proceeds it generates provides her with the financial means needed to support her family.

loans.use: To buy assorted raw materials for her fish cage like fishing net, bamboo, fingerlings, etc.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita A. is from the village of Inasagan, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 35 years old. Lolita is single and has six adult children. To make a living, Lolita owns and operates a business raising crops. Her main source of income comes from raising pigs in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lolita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to expand her business still more. This loan will be her fifth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is married with eight children and is 58 years old. She sells groceries to make a living and has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers.

Florence needs more funds to boost her business. She is requesting a loan of NGN 120,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella B. is from the village of Cabaruan. She is 36 years old. Estrella is married, with children. To make a living, Estrella owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling Avon cosmetics products in the local community. Estrella earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Estrella joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Estrella from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en: Narantuya is a 41-year-old widow who lives with her mother and her three children in a house in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. All of her children attend a local secondary school while Narantuya operates a grocery retail business. She began her business in 2003 after working for several years as a nurse. Her nursing salary was too low to support her family so she began her own business and she currently has a working capital of 2,000,000 tugrugs (~1400 USD), with monthly earnings between 300,000 and 450,000 tugrugs (~210-316 USD). In addition to her grocery business, she also sells coal and firewood in order to increase her earnings. Narantuya says, “All I want is to be able to afford my children’s education.” She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount of groceries for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for resale

loans.name: Amos

texts.en:
Amos is a 28-year-old married father of two. He operates a bread distribution business in Nairobi’s country bus station and a retail shop in the same location. He describes his business environment as stable and employs three people.

Amos has requested a loan of Kes 60,000 to add to his stock of bread for distribution. He hopes to buy a pick-up truck for bread distribution and to own a wholesale shop. He describes himself as hardworking, faithful and customer friendly.

loans.use: To add to his stock of bread

loans.name: Christine Awino

texts.en:
Christine Awino O. is a 53-year-old woman, a mother of six children and the sole proprietor of a cereals business. She mainly deals in maize, and occasionally wheat. She initially was a baker at the local market of Malanga, Busia district.

Christine requires a loan of 20,000 KES, which she says will go toward expanding her cereals business by buying more stock in bulk. Some will go to pay school fees for her children.

Her future plan and dream is to make sure her children attend school to the highest level, something she keeps insisting she should have not missed.

loans.use: Expand stock and pay school fees

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Teofila

texts.en:
Teofila A. is from the village of Inasagan, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 50 years old, is single, and has one adult child. Teofila owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling gas in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Teofila joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Teofila is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her fifth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Otgonjargal

texts.en:
Otgonjargal is 32 years old and lives with her mother and younger brother in the Zavhan province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her younger brother is a fireman for a private company.

Otgonjargol operates a grocery retail business out of a rented stall in her town. She began her business four years ago and, since then, has gained a lot of business experience and customers. She would like to eventually own her own shop so that she can grow her business and customer base.

Otgonjargal is a determined, hardworking young woman who reaches whatever goals she sets for herself. She is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount of food that she can sell to her customers for their New Year’s preparations.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of food

loans.name: Emin

texts.en: Emin A. is a hardworking man who has dedicated himself to making his business prosper through great effort. Nine years ago he began his grocery business, which is located in an open market. Over the years, he has improved the structure of his business. Emin is married and has an adorable daughter. His wife actively helps Emin and he feels happy and satisfied to work together with her. Thanks to his friendly and easy-going character, he has been able to expand his business and clientele. Now Emin is applying for a 1600 AZN loan to purchase more merchandise and to improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Evalyne

texts.en:
Evalyne A. is young mother of four children, married and 28 years old. Initially, before she ventured into her current fish business, she says she was confident as a housewife. That is until financial complications set in and she realized, she says, that two are better than one.

Evalyne would like a loan of 30,000 KES for the expansion of her fish business. Besides this she would like to invest in farming. Her future plan is to make sure her children have an education fund to guarantee the continuation of their schooling.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice sells cooking oil at retail prices to her customers. She sells her cooking oil at home and in the market and started this business seven years ago. Cooking oil is used in the preparation of Nigerian cooked foods. She loves this business because it is highly competitive.

Beatrice is 48 years old and is married with five children. Her children are excelling in school. Beatrice is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more cooking oil to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

Beatrice is a LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Florence Awino

texts.en:
Florence Awino O. is a mother of 9 children, all of whom are in school. She is also a wife and businesswoman. Her main business is selling fresh fish at the Malanga market, Busia district, Kenya. She also manages her farm where she sells fresh items straight from the farm. She would like a loan of KES 20,000 which will go into increasing her fish stock and expanding her farming area.

Her future plan is to ensure education for her children and expand both her businesses to become large scale.

loans.use: increase fish stock and expand farming area

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Saranchimeg

texts.en:
Saranchimeg is 34 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in a wooden house in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Both of her sons, aged 11 and 7, attend a local secondary school and her husband is a driving instructor.

Saranchimeg operates a beauty products retail business in a rented stall at a local retail center. She began her business in 2005 after working for several years as a nurse. Currently, she has a working capital that exceeds 5,000,000 tugrugs (~3450 USD) and has a monthly net profit of 300,000-500,000 tugrugs (~205-345 USD).

Saranchimeg has gained a lot of experience in her four years of operation and would like to keep growing her business in the future. She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a large amount of beauty products and to start selling phone cards at her business.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of beauty products and phone cards

loans.name: Javan Nangombe

texts.en:
For the last six years, Javan has run the “Javan Household Goods” store and has sold household goods such as cooking pans, basins, jugs, cups,machetes and rope to regular and walk-in customers. His business challenges are high transportation and storage costs.

Javan is using the proceeds of KES 60,000 to buy more stock like pans and basins. His goal in life is to run a wholesale shop.

Javan is married and has seven children ranging in age from one-and-a-half to twelve years. He describes himself as hardworking and determined.

loans.use: To restock goods sold

loans.name: Edoe

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur a appris l’électronique, en 2000 après sa formation il a ouvert sa propre boutique où il fait la réparation d’appareils électroniques et le vente d’antennes paraboliques, beaucoup de gens lui font confiance à cause de la qualité de ses services. En ce moment il a besoin de quelques matériaux pour son commerce, il sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour pouvoir acheter des accessoires et 08 antennes paraboliques.
Il est marié et père de 03 enfants.
texts.en:
This gentleman trained in electronics and after his studies ended in 2000 he opened his own store where he repairs electronics and sells satellite dishes. Many people trust him because of the high quality service he provides. He currently requires some materials for his business. He is therefore requesting a WAGES loan so that he can purchase electronic accessories and eight satellite dishes. He is married and the father of three children.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of electronics and satellite dishes

loans.name: Tsend-Ayush

texts.en: Tsend-Ayush is 39 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in a ger district on the outskirts of the city. Her two daughters both attend a local secondary school and Tsend-Ayush and her husband operate a traditional shoe business. She began her business in 2004 and produces 4-5 pairs of shoes per day. Her working capital now exceeds 800,000 tugrugs (~560 USD) and she would like to expand her business in the future. This is her second loan from Xac Bank, Kiva’s MFI partner. Tsend-Ayush is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan in order to purchase fabric and materials for her shoe business.

loans.use: to purchase fabric and materials

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora is 45 years old and is married with five children. She is a friendly and hardworking woman.

Dora sells children’s clothes and shoes of various sizes and colors. She purchases her goods from Onitsha and Lagos to sell at the market in Benin City, Edo state. This is the high season for business and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She hopes to own a boutique in the future.

Dora is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Dora needs a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more children’s clothes and shoes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more children's clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Gokhvar

texts.en: Gokhvar S. is 48 years old. She is married and the loving mother of two children. Gokhvar owns a successful clothing sales business in Imishli city. She has been doing this business for about 13 years. Her business has benefited from a good location and constant demand for her products. Gokhvar tries to offer good prices to her customers while still making a profit. Gokhvar has requested a loan of 1600 AZN to increase her inventory. This is a busy time for many vendors, as the cold season is coming and everyone is preparing for the winter. By purchasing additional inventory, Gokhvar will be better prepared to meet the increased demand and earn a good income. We believe her perseverance and natural liveliness will help her continue to succeed in her trade, and repay this loan on time.

loans.use: purchase clothes for winter season

loans.name: Bartholomen Nzilu

texts.en:
For the last year, Bartholomen Nzilu M. has run “Highway Properties” where he works as an agent selling land, plots and houses to regulars and walk-ins. He has two employees and faces the business challenges of lack of funds to promote his business and strong competition from similar business.

Bartholomen is using the proceeds of 50,000 KES to buy a computer, office stationery and to promote his business. He desires to be the main agent in the Mlolongo area which is near the Kitengela area. He describes himself as hardworking, polite and social.

loans.use: To buy another computer, office stationery and to advertise his business

loans.name: Akomola

texts.fr:
En 2006, ce monsieur a commencé le commerce en détail des gaz et des accessoires de gaz, il s’approvisionne au mali, au Ghana et au burkina. Il exerce son commerce dans le quartier de hedzranawoé qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé.  Son stock de marchandises est en  baisse, il souhaiterait s’approvisionner raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour l’achat de 7 brûleurs, 15 bouteilles de gaz, 10 cuisinières et 10 tuyaux.
Etant célibataire, le revenu de son commerce lui permet de subvenir aux charges de sa famille
texts.en:
In 2006 this gentleman started a business selling gas and gas accessories. He gets his supplies from Mali, Ghana and Burkina Faso. He runs his business in the Hedzranawoé district which is the peripheral area of the city of Lomé. His stock of merchandise is decreasing and he is requesting his first loan from WAGES in order to purchase seven gas burners, fifteen bottles of gas, ten gas stoves and 10 pipes. As he is single, the income from his business allows him to provide for his family.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of gas burners, bottles of gas, gas stoves, pipes, etc.

loans.name: Alice Anyango

texts.en: Alice Anyango O. is a 45 year old mother of 7 children. She specializes in farming; her major crops are maize and beans. Her initial business was poultry farming from which she supplied eggs to the Malanga market. She quit poultry farming after an outbreak of poultry disease in the area. She says her farming business has never been better because she is guaranteed two rainy seasons within the year. She would like a loan of KES 30,000 to increase her farming area, hire some labor, and get seedlings and fertilizer.

loans.use: to increase her farming area

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nyamjav

texts.en:
Nyamjav is 40 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in the Uvs province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both of his daughters, aged 13 and 8, attend a local secondary school while his wife helps him with the family business.

Nyamjav manages a clothing retail business which he began in 1992. When he first began his business he rented a stall in the local market but was able to move into his own shop in 2008 after many years of successful operation. He would like to eventually begin a shoe business which would utilize his wife’s knowledge of making shoes.

Nyamjav is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan in order to import a large amount of clothes from China for his business.

loans.use: To import a large amount of clothes from China

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita T. is a business-minded woman. She is 65 years old and the mother of two daughters and one son. Her husband passed away so she is now the single mother of her children. She lives in Jala-jala, in the province of Rizal, Philippines. She belongs to a poor family that needs help to change their standard of living and she is grateful to ASHI for support, even in all the challenges in life.

With her belief and faith in getting out of poverty, Lolita decided in 2009 to join ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with a chance of having start-up capital for generating income. During her first loan from ASHI, she carefully invested in her sari-sari store (a small retail store selling different goods). The profit is what she uses for daily expenses.

Now on her 2nd loan, Lolita proposes Php 10,000 to create a broader business. Specifically, the amount will be used to purchase sacks of rice, powdered milk, frozen foods, canned goods, candies, etc. She is very determined and disciplined to use the money which is lent to her. 

Lolita still dreams of the best for her family: to provide the best education for her children and to have a happy family. During her almost one year in ASHI, she has shown herself to be industrious and determined to make her dreams come true. She would love to have her own house someday.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her shop

loans.name: Osahon

texts.en:
Osahon is 39 years old and is married with four children. His children are excelling in school.

Osahon owns a chemist store (pharmacy) where he sells different types of medicines at retail prices. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He hopes to own a maternity home in the future.

Osahon is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Osahon is a LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is 28 years old and has a motorbike taxi business which he began two years ago. With this 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan, he hopes to purchase one more motorbike. It is very important to him that he be known as a reliable driver, and he describes himself as reserved but very focused. He is married and has two children who are both attending school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity is 60 years old and is a widow with two children. Both of her children are grown up and they are married with children. Charity is happy because she is a grandmother.

Charity sells drinks and cooking oil at retail prices to her customers and has been in this business for a long time. Her greatest joy in her business is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers.

Charity needs a loan of NGN 140,000 to purchase more drinks and cooking oil to sell. She hopes to expand her business in future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Charity is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Genen

texts.en:
Genen is a 57-year-old widower who lives with his three adult children in a house in the Uvs province of Mongolia. All three of his children work and Genen operates a saddle-making business in his town. He began his business in 2006 and, even though he has only operated for a short amount of time, he has earned a very good reputation among his customers for his crafting skills. In the future, he would like to help his daughter start a traditional shoe making business since she has been trained in this type of craft. In the near future, he would like to earn enough money to refurbish his home to make it more comfortable for his family.

Genen is requesting a 300,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more materials for his saddle business.

loans.use: To purchase raw material for saddle making

loans.name: Tchilalo

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité la vente de boissons locales alcoolisées appelées "Toucoutchou" qui est faite à base de mil et est très appréciée par les togolais,elle a plus de 7 ans d’expérience dans ce commerce ce qui fait qu’elle est très connue et a une parfaite maîtrise de son activité. Elle s’approvisionne en mil à l’intérieur du pays  plus précisément dans la ville d’anié et de kara. Voulant se réapprovisionner en mil parce que son stock de mil épuisé, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de  20 sacs de mil.
Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman sells a local alcoholic drink known as "Toucoutchou," made from millet and much appreciated by Togolese people. She has been in this business more than seven years, is well known and an expert in what she does. She buys millet in central Togo, specifically in the towns of Anie and Kara. She wishes to buy more because her stock is depleted. She is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy 20 sacks, She is married and has six children.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy millet.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Storage and retail of cereals

loans.name: Julia Auma

texts.en: Julia Auma O. is a rare kind of a woman. She is 50 years old, a mother of 7 and sole owner of a business most women consider a man's job. Julia runs a timber sales business in Malanga, Busia district. She has been doing this for well over 5 years. Like all timber tradespeople in the area, she buys a mature tree and develops it to timber before transportation to her store. Her labor force is comprised of men and, she says if it was not for her age, she would probably join them in the work as she used to. She requires a loan of KES 20,000 which will be used to replace her old wood cutting power saw. Her future plan is to expand into other towns.

loans.use: Buy a power saw

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sotoewa

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et mère d’un enfant, l’activité qu’elle exerce est le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, son époux est un chauffeur et son revenu ne lui permet pas de couvrir toutes les charges de la famille, avec  son revenu elle apporte sa contribution financière à son foyer. Elle veut profiter des fêtes de fin d’année pour bien vendre, raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour compléter son stock avec 15 boîtes de tomates, 3 paniers de tomates naturel et 5 cartons de pâtes alimentaires.
texts.en:
This woman is married and has a child and she buys and sells food. Her husband is a chauffeur but his income does not cover all the family expenses. With her income she contributes to the home finances. She wishes to take advantage of the holidays to improve her sales, therefore she is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to complement her stock with 15 cans of tomatoes, 3 baskets of fresh tomatoes and 5 boxes of pasta.

Translated from French by caroline Mrejen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food (tomatoes and pasta)

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: For the last four years, Lilian M. has been selling weaves to employees who work at salons. Her business is in Khayega, a semi-urban town. She also owns a power saw that she rents out. Previously, she used to sell cereals. Her business challenges are inflation and low demand from her customers. She is using this loan of 55,000 Kenyan shillings to diversify her business by adding more stock of weaves and buying another power saw. Her goal in life is to run a boutique and own ten power saws to rent. Lilian is married and has three children. She describes herself as hardworking and dedicated to her work.

loans.use: To buy weaves and another power saw

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose, 47, is married and has four children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community called Axim, in the western region of Ghana. Rose works hard to support her husband to be able to provide for the family. She trades in onions, supplying to retailers and food vendors in her community as well as nearby communities.  In business for  over 20 years, Rose is now requesting a loan to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy onions

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Storage and retail of corn

loans.name: Monica Atieno

texts.en: Monica runs the MJ Tailoring business and sells clothes to frequent and new customers.  She has one employee and has been in the business for fourteen years.  Her business challenge is a lack of funds to buy materials for making clothes.  She is using the proceeds of KES50,000 to buy more materials.  In the future, she wants to open a big shop in a good location.  Monica is a widow and has two children.  She describes herself as hardworking and dedicated to her work.

loans.use: To buy more material for making clothes

loans.name: Afiwa

texts.fr: Résidente du quartier d’adidogomé qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé, cette femme est mariée et mère de 04 enfants. Pour aider son époux dans les charges de la famille, elle a   entamée la vente en détail des ustensiles de cuisine. Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises en Europe. Elle voudrait gonfler son stock pour augmenter son chiffre d’affaire raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 30 plats, 10 couteaux de cuisine, 25 cuillères, 25 fourchettes, 10 tasses et divers autres ustensiles.
texts.en:
Resident of the Adidogomé district, a suburb of the city of Lomé, this woman is married and the mother of 4 children. In order to help her husband with the household expenses, she began selling kitchen utensils. She buys her goods in Europe. She wishes to increase her stocks and for that reason she is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase 30 serving platters, 10 kitchen knives, 25 spoons, 25 forks, 10 cups and various other utensils.

Translated from French by caroline Mrejen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Retail of kitchen utensils

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna G., 58 years old, comes from Morong, in the growing province of Rizal, where there are many enterprises. She is married to Dario G., a farmer.  She is a diligent and careful mother of two children.
Myrna's husband's income is not enough to meet the needs of their family. Therefore, in 2005, Myrna got the idea of joining ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. She was given hope and a way to have access to capital, so she started her printing business. The business went smoothly and brings them good income. She is also involved in the farming business and they help each other in running their family businesses.

Currently on her sixth loan, Myrna proposes the amount of Php 30,000 as additional capital to purchase stock and more supplies for her printing business. Stock includes items such as T-shirts for printing, assorted paints, and silk; the loan will also be use for purchasing fertilizer for their farming business.

Myrna has disciplined herself to use all of the borrowed capital from ASHI-KIVA for her business, in order to gain more profit and to use that profit to support daily expenses.

She has been an ASHI member for four years (4).  ASHI paved the way for the achievement of the dreams of her family, to send her children to school and to finish their studies with a degree. She also hasn't stopped dreaming for her grandchildren, and wants to offer them the best education, such as she provided for her children. The couple feels very happy with the loan that made their lives to be better than before. Myrna wishes all lenders all the best and good luck and will continue to support her family and the expanded business.

loans.use: Purchase of materials for printing business (T-shirts, assorted paints,silk) and also fertilizer for farming business.

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en:
Beauty is 38 years old and is married with six children. Her children are excelling in school.

Beauty owns a grocery stall where she sells drinks and groceries to make a living. She has been in this business since 2001 and makes more sales from her drinks business. She sells for long hours to enable her meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future.

Beauty is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks and groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Beauty is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and groceries to sell

loans.name: Jane Rose

texts.en:
Jane Rose A. O. is a businesswoman who sells fish while at the same time running a farm. She is a mother of six children and at the age of 38, she says she is at her business prime age. 

Jane would like to restock her fish supply so as to maintain a stable stock and also buy more seeds in preparation for the early rains in 2010. She would like a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings for her to achieve all these goals.

loans.use: Restock fish and buy seeds for farming

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Phoebe

texts.en: Phoebe is married with 4 children. She is 43 years old. She sells sarongs and laces of various attractive colors to make a living. She also has another stall where she sells groceries. This is the high season for business and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She uses her experience in the business to attract more customers to her stall. She loves this business because her customers pay cash when they come to purchase sarongs or laces. She needs a loan of 180,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs and laces to sell. She says a big thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and laces to sell

loans.name: Big Family Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Big Family' Group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the small town of Waterloo, near Freetown. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,800,000 to enable them to expand their businesses.

The leader of this group is Frances N. on the left in the photo. Frances N. is a trained nurse and owns a pharmacy in Waterloo’s main market. In her pharmacy, she sells pain medicines, medicines for colds and malaria. Frances has been selling medicines in this pharmacy for seven years now. With this loan, she will travel to neighboring Guinea as usual to buy in larger quantity the above mentioned medicines.

Frances was born in Kenema, eastern Sierra Leone. She is thirty years of age, single with one child and four foster children. Four of these children are attending secondary schools and one is in primary school.

loans.use: buy pain medicines, medicines for colds, and malaria medicines in larger quantity

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer R. was born in the province of Tanay in the Philippines. She is 26 years old, married to Crisanto R. and has three (3) children: two in elementary and one is an 18 month-old baby. A few weeks ago, the couple separated but Jennifer has a strong belief not to be affected by it; instead she is inspired to work hard for her children. Presently she is the head of the family, a provider for her family's needs. 

She joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap Inc.), a KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2004; she has grown to love the organization. ASHI helped her in the start-up of a business, supporting her husband in their daily expenditures. She and her husband had been in the fishing business for more than six (6) years. She now proposes that her eighth loan amounting Php 17,000.00 be used to continue the fishing business without the support of her husband. She will purchase assorted raw materials of her fishing business like fishnet, rope, steel, bamboo, threads, etc.

She dreams that soon she will have a wider space to store her fishing materials. She dreams also that she will send her children to school and see them finish their studies. Jennifer wants to thank ASHI for all its initiatives for the poor and the Kiva lenders who will sponsor this loan. Like most families here in the Philippines, they are dreaming for the best in life and also a happy family.

loans.use: To buy raw materials of her fishing business (fishnet, rope, steel, bamboo, threads, etc.)

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia is a 39 year old single mother of one daughter aged 13. She supplies chicken and fish in Nairobi and describes her business environment as competitive. She employs one person and hopes to expand her business and start supplying beyond Nairobi and become an established business lady. She has requested a second loan of Kes. 50,000 to add stock after successful repayment of her first Kes. 50,000 loan. She describes herself as humble and hardworking.

loans.use: Add stock of chicken and fish to her business.

loans.name: Maurice Were

texts.en: Maurice Were O. is 58 years of age, married and a father of 12 children. His main source of income to provide for his family is farming. He is a former civil servant and, after retirement, he ventured into farming as a means of self-employment. Maurice would like a loan of KES 20,000 which will be used to buy seeds and fertilizer in preparation for the oncoming rains in early 2010. Maurice is a jovial individual and his main plan and dream is to always manage to ensure food security for his family while acquiring income from farming at the local market where he sells his produce.

loans.use: buy seeds and fertilizer

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is thirty-four years old. She is married and has given birth to five children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing business is the major occupation of the people. Cecilia is a baker. She bakes bread and supplies it to retailers and beverage sellers. She has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to buy bags of flour and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour and other ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is 49 years old and a mother of five children. She is a focused hard worker. She hopes to lift her business and family above poverty. She sells frozen foods such as turkey, chicken, and iced fish to make a living. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profits. She hopes to own a butcher shop in the future. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 142,000 NGN to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Dipase Jonathan

texts.en: Dipase Jonathan O. is a 43 year old father of 2 who is separated from his wife. He is the guardian of his children and a poultry farmer in Malanga, Busia district. Dipase says that life gets a little difficult because he has to be both father and mother. He says he is not in hurry to remarry; his main concerns are his poultry business and the well being of his children. Dipase would like a loan of KES 30,000 which will be used to finance the new vegetable business at his farm. He says the customer base is already set and business has picked up.  He needs to finance the business both in terms of labor (because he cannot be everywhere at the same time) and expansion of the planting area.

loans.use: expand into vegetable farming

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Efosa

texts.en: Efosa is married with 4 children and she is 38 years old. She sells drinks at wholesale and retail prices. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profits. She hopes to be a major drink distributor in the future. She has been in this business for 4 years. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She needs a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en: Sophia is thirty-eight years old. She is married and has given birth to six children, all of whom are still in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing business is the major occupation of the people. Sophia is a trader. She trades in cereals such as maize, rice, beans, etc. She buys from nearby communities and treks to sell in nearby towns. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy cereals for trade

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena is thirty-seven years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing business is the major occupation of the people. Philomena is a trader. She trades in salt. She buys bags of salt from cargo cars that come round to distribute. She treks to sell in nearby towns and also supplies it to food vendors. Philomena has been in business for fifteen years and wants a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of salt to trade

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary B. is from the village of Balanlinao, Plaridel Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old. Rosemary is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosemary owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Rosemary has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosemary joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemary is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosemary from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Donald

texts.en:
Donald A. is a 32 year old man blessed with 6 children. He is a poultry and cereals farmer in Malanga, Busia District. He believes in walking the talk by setting goals and living up to them.

He ocassionaly ventures into brick making during the Christmas holidays since, he says, most town folks tend to start building houses as tradition requires in the village. 

Donald would like a loan of Kshs. 30,000 to expand his cereal business. His future plan is to venture into dairy farming.

loans.use: Expand business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Masiaday Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Masiaday' group. Members of the 'Masiaday' group are small-scale businesswomen in the small town of Waterloo, near Freetown. They have come to SMT, a partner of 'Shine on Sierra Leone' in Waterloo to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 each to boost their businesses.

The leader of this group is Yeabu K. in the middle. Yeabu was born in a place call Nabina in Gambia, northern Sierra Leone. She is approximately fifty-three years old, a widow with four children. One of her children is in university; two are in secondary school, and one in primary school. 

Yeabu sells cooked rice and 'foofoo' (food made out of ground cassava). She has been a businesswoman for unknown number of years now. With this loan, she will buy ten gallons of palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), five gallons of other oil, three bags of rice, one bag of onions and an unknown number of fish and other cooking ingredients.

loans.use: Buy ten gallons of palm-oil, five gallons of other oil, three bags of rice, etc.

loans.name: Benita

texts.en:
Benita E. is from the village of Balanlinao, Plaridel Mis. Occ. She is 60 years old. Benita is widowed and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Benita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, vinegar, soy sauce, sugar & toothpaste in the local community. Benita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Benita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benita is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Benita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional daily-use products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stocking up on general foodstuffs for his shop

loans.name: Kholniso

texts.en:
K. Kholniso is a 31-year-old man who is married with two children. Thanks to his father (pictured), who is a farmer, Kholniso has been associated with this business since he was young. He purchases the sheep in the local market and then he breeds and sells them. The sheep are kept in the house and it takes a lot of effort to care for them. Every day, Kholniso gets up early in the morning in order to feed the animals. All day, until late at night, he is busy looking after the sheep. Kholniso says that he works with only one aim in mind - to provide his children with proper education. Now, Kholniso would like to expand his business and purchase more sheep. For this purpose, he has applied for $900 USD and with your help he hopes to reach his aim.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of sheep to expand the business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stocking up her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cosmetics for her hair salon.

loans.name: Good Family Group

texts.en:
These are members of the 'Good Family' group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in the small town of Waterloo, near Freetown. They have been in business for many years now but business has been growing at a very slow pace for these entrepreneurs. They therefore decided to form themselves into a group of three and apply for a loan from SMT/Kiva. With the help of a loan, they can expand their businesses and make more sales and better profit. Consequently, they can better provide for themselves and their children.

The leader of this group of borrowers is Musu M. on the left. Musu was born in Waterloo, forty-seven years ago. She is a widow with four children. Two of her children are attending school – one in primary and the other in secondary school.

Musu owns a bar where she sells hard drinks, soft drinks, luncheon meat, sardines, baked beans, cigarettes, and so on. She has been in this business for more than twenty years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy two crates of beer, two crates of stout, one carton of Codys and one carton of Carlsberg.

loans.use: Buy two crates of beer, two crates of stout, etc.

loans.name: Khuram

texts.en: Khuram K. is 49 years old. He lives with his wife and four children. He has been breeding sheep for more than seven years and is trying to improve the breed in order to increase his prices. He invests time and money in the feed and medicines that the animals require. Khuram keeps going thanks to the help and enthusiasm of his children and his wife, who also helps him care for the animals. Now Khuram needs a loan of 4,500 Somoni for purchasing more sheep to expand his business. With your help this will be possible. loans.name: Suyum

texts.en: Suyum K. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and five children. He is a farmer dedicated to studying the land and to the cultivation of different crops. His farming generates earnings that allow him to support his family. Suyum takes his products to the town of Shahrituz to sell throughout the primary markets of that town. Suyum is always vigilant of his farmland, making sure to keep tabs on any possible pest infestations or diseases that may harm his crops. Suyum is motivated, day in and day out, by his desire to better provide for his family and by his wish for his children to complete their education so that they can look forward to bright futures. He seeks a loan with which to buy products for planting his crops, such as seeds and fertilizer, to be able to improve his yield in the future. The well-being of this family is in your hands.
